column10:
Scrap Mechanic is a game with great promise. I'm recommending it, but only very narrowly.

Scrap Mechanic does two things very well - you can create vehicles with a high degree of freedom and customize your character. I really liked these portions of the game. The vehicle creation is the perfect combination of intuitive yet complex that is hard to achieve. Aesthetically, the game looks great. It's strong systems as well as the potential it has likely justify its $20 price tag.

Scrap Mechanic has an early combat system that is somewhat lackluster. You hit things with a hammer until you're well into the mid game, at which point there are a few varieties of guns and vehicular weapons. There are two types of enemies in the early game that, while looking good, behave very similarly. The hammer doesn't really have any stratagem involved - you cannot power attack, block, upgrade it or your armor, or heal during combat. You can hurl water out of refillable buckets at your enemies to momentarily stun them (and enemies do a reasonable job of dodging to make you time this carefully), but eventually you end up swinging with your hammer again and trading blows. Combat becomes a chore since you have to slowly regenerate health between fights or exploit the nearest body of water to reliably fight off 3-4 enemies.

As your progression to mid-game is largely blocked by your ability to acquire scrap metal, components kits, and circuit boards, the game ends up steering you away from activities that it does well and are entertaining back to a combat system that is arguably less well developed than Minecraft's. This is true for both picking out new clothes and building sick rides - you keep getting funneled into raiding ruins for the aforementioned goods so you can build the next vehicle part. I wouldn't even say that this experience is bad so much as it just feels tedious. 

I would suggest the following for future development:

1. Improve early game combat with the hammer by making it quickly upgrade-able with scrap metal and/or giving the player other melee combat abilities (power attacks, blocking, healing during combat, etc.). Consider increasing scrap and component rewards to circumvent the tedium, since this steers the player back to what the game does right faster.

2. Decrease the crafting requirements for the level 1 chest and offer this in the initial craft bot menu. This will give the initial 'scrap' vehicle that is slower than the player can run an actual purpose beyond being a tutorial car.

3. I would consider making crafting stations craft-able by the player. Location locking where you can create these on the map feels limiting to me, though I appreciate that you can move them once created.

I think this is especially important since players could refund the game before getting to the more enjoyable portions of it.

This game is a creative and sandbox game, where I can build amazing machines and vehicles from scrap parts. The game has a lot of freedom and possibilities, with different modes, tools, and components. The game also has a multiplayer mode, where I can play with my friends and share my creations. The game also has a survival mode, where I have to scavenge, craft, and fight against hostile robots.

However, the game also has some drawbacks that lower the quality. The game is still in early access, and it has many bugs, glitches, and crashes. The game can also be very demanding and laggy, especially on low-end computers. The game can also be very complex and confusing, especially for new players, as there is no proper tutorial or guide. The game can also be very repetitive and boring, as there is not much variety or challenge in the gameplay.

Overall, I think this game is a fun and innovative game, but it also has some flaws that need to be improved. I would recommend this game to creative and curious players who love building and experimenting, but not to players who expect a smooth and polished game.

You’ll want a good computer to run it. Not the fastest computer made with love by NASA, but at the very least something classified for medium to high tier games.
There are three main game modes: Creative, challenge, and survival. 
Creative is great for people who like making shit. Also, the in game world editor expands these possibilities. This mode is the core part of the game and is what you are mainly paying for at this time.
Challenge mode is good for puzzles and sharing yours with other people. Think of it like the type of game Portal and Portal 2 are centered around. This time while making shit, you can have people walk around your shit via Workshop.
Survival is ok. It has grind but not too much. There isn’t a whole lot of content either at the moment, only a small story in the very start of game play. Mods [strike]aren’t[/strike] [b]are now[/b] officially integrated into survival, called custom gamemodes. Some examples are Fant Mod, centered around new tech, and Crashlander, centered around a story. If all you want is the pure survival gameplay, I’d look into it more or wait for caves and bosses to be added. 

There is also co-op with friends. My experience was laggy but I believe it may be a host issue. 

In summary, it’s good for an early access but should still be microwaved for another minute.

Good idea on paper, even looks pretty, but horrible execution. Unlike other sandbox games, in this one, if you build anything, you will be attacked. Not once, no, there's a timer that tells you when the next attack will come. There is absolutely nothing you can do to prevent attacks. Moreover, the parts you need just to build a simple cart are spread out across ruins filled with enemies that can and will swarm you. When you die, you drop all your stuff. So, you go to find new things, lose all your old gear, respawn far away, and without your stuff, it is now much harder to reclaim your stuff.

Edit: I made that review years ago and absolutely nothing has changed since then. Don't buy this game.

I have owned this game for over 5 years on 3 different devices. I have no clue how to build a simple car. Yes i am an idiot.

The latest update has been taking well over 2+ years now, which is interesting.  But besides that, it's a great game for what it has right now.  Great mix of peaceful gameplay and absolute terror when the farmbots come to wreak havoc on your crops.  :)

Your imagination is the limit when it comes to creating solutions to any of your problems.  Bearings, engines, logic gates and timers let you go nuts with your creations, well beyond just vehicles.  Automate your doors and lights in your base, put your base on your car!  Have some pistons and timers?  Slap a watergun and tank next to your farm with just a few sensors and auto water your crops when needed.

Can't wait for the next chapter update!

Ah yes, Scrap Mechanic, the game where your dreams of engineering genius collide with the harsh reality of building a vehicle that looks like it's held together by duct tape and hope.

Imagine building a car that you swear will revolutionize the automotive industry, only to witness it doing the cha-cha with a tree before bursting into flames. Scrap Mechanic is that perfect blend of creativity and calamity – a masterpiece of engineering followed by an epic fail that leaves you wondering if you should stick to simpler hobbies, like knitting or napping.

Physics, the unsung hero of Scrap Mechanic. Prepare to witness the laws of nature take a vacation as your vehicles somersault through the air like acrobatic whales attempting synchronized swimming. The game's physics engine operates on the philosophy of "the more absurd, the better." Who needs realism when you can have your vehicle spontaneously combust just because it feels like it?

If you wanna play multiplayer the game is highly unreliable with massive desync, if you're unlucky.

My experience, host and client, two beefy 2 y.o. computers with low ping, none/low package loss, fiber between, have almost 1 minute desync on client making driving and fighting a somewhat confusing experience, even from the first minute of playing at the crash site.

I, on the client, made our first vehicle and drove off in one direction while host looked at me trying to drive into trees and water. 30 seconds later I rubberbanded into same water.
Or when I killed a farmbot that was hitting "air", just to get all those hits on me 30 or so seconds later, killing me. Super fun.

I read that some have no problems while other have the same problems as me or worse.

Edit: Singleplay, it's fun

I first bought this game back in 2016, just a few months after entering Early Access. Back then, the game had really great promise and actually had semi-regular updates. [spoiler](Real shocker, I know!)[/spoiler] Development eventually slowed down, but not so much that it felt like the devs abandoned us. Once the Survival Update hit in 2020 [u](almost exactly 4 years after I bought it)[/u], I thought development would pick back up.

[h1]BOY WAS THAT A FREAKING LIE!!![/h1]
After Survival released, we had only a few other updates, one to fix and restore Challenge Mode, and the other to update creative mode with the new stuff. After that... nothing. Occasionally a Devblog or small (And I mean [i]small[/i]) update, but still nothing.

4 years later in 2024, still nothing. Near total radio silence. Supposedly they post teasers or something on Twitter, but I haven't even seen anything that looks good in those post as it is. I don't even use Twitter anyway and I genuinely couldn't care less what happens there.

There are many games that entered and left Early Access in less than half the time since this game first became available. 8 years is clearly more than enough time to make a quality game. The developers keep saying "We're working real hard," and "The next update is coming soon," but in the last 5 or so years, they have failed to deliver on any promises they've made outside of delivering Survival mode. Unless they have some [b]MAJOR[/b] comeback, and [u]actually[/u] start producing regular updates and manage to maintain some level of contact with the community, then the game is going to end up Dead On Arrival.

At this current point, I cannot recommend you buy this game or support the developers in any way. If it looks cool to you and you really want to blow $20, be my guest, but don't say I didn't warn you.
I LOVE ME

I really, really want to give this game a thumbs up but I can't. This game is basically abandonware at this point with how frequent updates are. 
   
   You know when the last major update was that actually added content? It was 3 years ago. 3 years. On top of that, you hardly ever get any updates on how progress is going and the developers haven't said anything to the community for over 4 months. This is an amazing game with amazing potential, but it's run its course. These developers are severely neglecting this game and its community to the point that it's on its last legs.
   
   That's not even the best part. Despite the horrible update schedule and lack of communication, they are STILL trying to make another game at the same time that this game, Scrap Mechanic, has been in early access for almost 8 years. Just a couple months ago they filed for the trademark for the name "Crew Commander." How about instead of making this "Crew Commander" game, you command your dev team to do their job? 

   Scrap mechanic is the embodiment of great potential with little care. It all solely relies on its community to provide content to the game because the studio that made it can't do so itself. At this point, the people in the game's community have probably made more content for the game than Axolot themselves. I would like you to picture Scrap Mechanic without mod support and without custom tiles, maps, community creations, and mods. How long would you play? All of those are because of the community. They are the life force of the Scrap Mechanic community and it's dying. 

  It's sad. Sad that such a promising game has had such neglect. Sad that such a hopeful community has been abandoned. Sad that this game studio cannot set its priorities straight. Sad that we might never see a full release of Scrap Mechanic. Axolot, please fix your dying game.

Scrap Mechanic isn't just a game; it's a workshop of wonders, a virtual playground where creativity knows no bounds. Developed by Axolot Games, this sandbox engineering game invites players to design and construct their own custom vehicles, contraptions, and inventions using a variety of scrap materials and components.

Whether you're building a towering robot, a flying machine, or a rolling fortress, Scrap Mechanic offers endless possibilities for invention and innovation. With its intuitive building tools and realistic physics engine, bringing your creations to life has never been easier or more rewarding.

And once you've built your masterpiece, it's time to put it to the test in a variety of action-packed game modes, from multiplayer races to survival challenges. With its vibrant community and regular updates, Scrap Mechanic offers endless hours of fun and excitement for players of all ages.

So whether you're a master engineer or just getting started, grab your wrench, fire up your imagination, and prepare to embark on the adventure of a lifetime in Scrap Mechanic. The only limit is your creativity.

(updated long-term review)

-This review is a summary and my closing thoughts on what this game is from long-term experience playing it. I will also share my thoughts on it as an amateur engineer.


General review.

     This game released into early access when I was in middle school. Most of my experiences came from the years predating survival mode (I still do not consider survival mode, and I will get to those reasons later on). As of the time of this review, I am a freshman in college studying mechanical engineering partially because of this game's existence.
     In the first 3 years of this game, I got into a booming community with many up-coming YouTubers who created their own communities. I spent most of that time doing casual building and making friends. At the time, the limitations were up to how much fun you can have with others, and how much you can contribute to a community.
     Survival came along, and the game died. All of the game's focus went towards grinding in survival mode (not fun) and discovering (a lack of) story. When I mean "died", I mean, the community would never return to the fun state that it started in. YouTubers had been leaving the game to pursue other, more rewarding games and content creation that would result in the immense success of those content creators.. but nobody seriously came back after survival's release in 2019.
     Between 2019 and present day, my experiences have been about pushing the game's creative mode boundaries. Not often have I played with friends to just mess around, nor have I returned to casual playing - because that became boring, especially with no community to look forward to taking part in. For fun, you must take on a very pro-level project such as replicating something from real life, putting a ton of details into a build, or build a "Hide and Seek" map. Chances are, the game will become boring because it lacks the ability to discover, progress, and as of today's state of community, well, a lack of community.

     Why don't I consider survival mode? It is because it put a big dent on the game's potential. The developers are stuck in a loop of what they wanted their game to be from the start. They have never paid attention to their own community, they have never made any attempt at all to try to connect with their community. As a result of the bad connection, the community faded. We now have a game that has little ties to the people who actually played in its early stages. Survival's development halted the potential of the game because 6 years of time was spent to add content - with no improvement on the game. You will encounter a bug, glitch, or lack of optimization at minimum once every time you play the game.

     Why did this game have potential? It is because of what the game is at its core. It is an open world physics sandbox that is nothing like any other game. You can build creations that are a part of the world, build a house, build a car, build a plane, any form of transportation you can think of, all in the same game. Build a city block-by-block? sure! You can even do programming with integrated logic parts, let alone the fact that you can control mechanical mechanisms using logic. The modding community (of the past) worked really hard to to create what the community wanted, to see through the game's potential, and take advantage of it, which enhanced the possibilities. It is because of the game's core that I loved it, and I would recommend it to anyone for those reason.

     What is the game now? The game is now "Scrap Mechanic Survival Mode" and NOT "Scrap Mechanic". People come to this game because of survival mode, which is not the iconic identity of the game. Survival mode is a disappointment due to a lack of story and progression, LOTS of material grinding, and no clear end goal. The only reason to play survival mode years-on-end is to build a pointless base. You do not even need to build anything to 'complete' this game. Just build a basic vehicle, and live in a pre-generated structure. Since this is considered as an 'engineering sandbox' I was expecting survival mode to have more automation, the need for specialized transportation systems, a way to build a running civilization, but no, the focus is on the story, world exploration, boss fighting, and a lot of resource grinding.
     To put into perspective, I played survival mode between the 2019 release, and 2020. I completed everything there was to complete, and I got bored. Building a base was all that I could do, and I never saw a clear end goal in needing to do that. I would rather build a bunch of cool stuff in creative mode than waste hours grinding away at getting materials just to 'automate' or 'advance' something with no end-goal use. It is currently post-2023 and the developers have still not made a major game-changing update since the survival update in 2019. This game might as well be abandon-ware for that reason.


Game perspective as an amateur engineer.

     This is a fun game to pass time, explore mechanics, and for younger people, a great way to introduce yourself into engineering. You are limited by very basic mechanic principles, which is just enough for beginner exploration - It is what got me interested in engineering and design.
     Do I recommend this for professionals? no. It is advertised as a game to "engineer your adventures" but the reality is, there is no adventure to 'engineer' and you will do zero engineering. Sure, designing an advanced survival mode farm with self-defense systems for 'raids' is engineering, however, that is just about the only thing in this game that has a problem to solve with many ways of doing it. For the level of engineering required to play this game, any kid can do, which is fine, but that means that there is no advanced problems to solve, you can only create your own advanced problems by over-engineering what is already easy to do. Survival mode aside, in creative mode you must accept that what you build is more so for the art of building and designing, which is true about creative mode of any game. You never get to actually solve problems.


Why I still play this game.

     I only play this game as a hobby. It is a way for me to relieve my brain of the creativity need especially when I do not have available time or resources for real life projects. With that said, just about any game can relieve me of that need such that I do not depend on this game. Unfortunately, the only way to feel accomplishment in this game is to do a large project, which either results in many flops, or a creation that gets little attention from the wrong people. If you design a build for the intent of engineering something for other players, a player will spawn it in to check it out once, and never look at it again. No point in trying to do advanced engineering for that reason. So, I am left with just building things for myself for fun. The game is just another tool for that, and is not unique from any other game.


What this game should have been.

     This game never needed to be a physics sandbox. The developers should have focused on the story aspects of a basic survival building game. It could have been a lot more like Minecraft, a creative and survival game that has no physics or mechanics to it. If the focus of the developers is truly on the survival mode story, they wasted their time by designing a physics sandbox game. Up until now, the game's design could be modified to not majorly rely on physics or building with mechanical parts. 'pre-sets' could have been used to make vehicles, with players not needing any background knowledge on how to build things.
     Long story short, this game from the beginning had untapped potential, with the wrong developers, and the current development of the game does not require a highly potential physics sandbox to achieve. There is more to the game than there needs to be.

This is an odd one. In many ways, this game is like a box of Technic LEGO with no instructions. You need to make your own fun with the parts that you are given.

At the basic level, you will probably design a car for travel, a machine for cutting trees, and a machine for mining stone. After that, you need to find a reason to build anything else, as there are very few reasons to proceed with farming or exploration within the game world. The only additional material beyond those basic activities are the warehouses, which are like a sort of dungeon with rare loot at the end. Personally, I find the warehouses to be extremely challenging and very fun, and I have a lot of ideas for tiny vehicles for breaching them.

But, here's where things get odd.

This game was first released 8 years ago. The last devlog on their own official website is from 7 years ago. Their Facebook page was last updated 4 years ago. Twitter is similarly dated, although at least has posts from within a year ago. Despite this, there are devlogs posted on the publisher's website (Axolot Games) showing off planned content from as recent as last year (and a hotfix was released only a couple months before my posting this review). In other words, the game [i]is[/i] being worked on, but the dev team is essentially no-contact and the whole situation feels like the game has been abandoned.

Despite this, I have been having a blast and I don't see myself slowing down! I spent a week designing a tank with complex driving logic and a high-volume rotary cannon for killing big red bots and [i]it actually works as designed[/i].

In my opinion, this is a complete game. If no new content is ever added, it's still a very enjoyable sandbox of blocks. I can readily do things in this game that I have wished for years that I could do in Minecraft. Like I said, it's LEGO with no instructions, but the box of parts is overflowing.

For the gameplay itself, in spite of what you might read about the physics engine, it's surprisingly reliable. For example, I built a scissor lift that actually functions as intended. I also built a hanging bridge that forms a proper catenary when draped. None of these things lag out my system. People have built actual working piston engines.

For comparison, I once tried to build a bit of landing gear in Space Engineers that was an arm on a hinge pushed out by a piston and it caused my entire ship to slowly rotate due to phantom forces, even when stationary. That is quite possibly the most simplistic machine linkage that anyone could ever build, except perhaps a lever. Yesterday, in Scrap Mechanic, I built a Scott Russell linkage that functions perfectly (just Google it, it's neat).

That said, it does get weird when you use a spinning thing to spin a thing.

The music is nice. The dynamic lighting looks really good when done properly. The enemy AI is a mixed bag. It's a bit clever, but not brilliant, either. The story is about 3 minutes long and doesn't even cover the bare minimum (ie, it doesn't explain trading).

Survival mode is very fun once you get rolling, but the initial start is the most disrespectful game I have ever played in terms of the player's time. It takes [i]hours[/i] of manual farming and grinding just to get the basic materials you need for chests and a small vehicle that isn't absolute ass. Farming glue is a horrendous waste of time that I literally just bypass by cheating (the only thing in survival that I cheat at, but I do it shamelessly in this case).

If you like designing machines to solve specific problems, buy this game! Which is to say, if you ever wanted to get into designing robots, or have very fond memories of MindStormz LEGO, then it is a ridiculous amount of fun.

The game itself is a wonderful concept and the gameplay is a fun dynamic. However..... But at this point I don't see it ever getting finished.

This game is like a toast...

Your first attempt at toast looks pretty good, but you end up burning it.
You don't give up, after several attempts you make some better toasts
Those toasts taste awful and one nearly burns your entire house down
Desperate for toasting glory you search for some toast videos on youtube
All these people making enoromous and gloriously looking toasts make you jealous and sad
One day, you discover that you sorta don't need to make overcomplicated toasts to enjoy your snack. You also notice tiny differences between toasts and their preparation
You finally enjoy a proper toast, but the more you eat, the hungrier you get
Your hunger for toasts gets bigger and bigger with every known recipe
You start modifying your snacks and try challenges from other toast fans
You achieve toasting heaven, nothing can stop you now, you have mastered the art of toast. You begin preparing your masterpiece.
After several hours of hard work you end up burning it.
You look back at all your progres, and you realize that you don't have to make every toast perfect. It's in the dedication, will to learn from your mistakes and enjoying little victories on long and hard path.

This game is sweet combination of pride, joy and relief you'll feel after every successful mission although you also get hours of excrutiating pain, swearing and mental breakdowns. Get this game for full price, it's worth every penny.

...and I like toasts.

Fun to build cars and test suspension geometry.

Don't get me wrong, it's a fun game. And the creative aspect (especially in the unlimited, creative mode - separate from the main "story mode") is quite good, even despite wonky physics and dreadfully bad optimisation. 
The tiny chunk of the story mode is quite good too. And I do admit, I did have quite a bit of fun playing through it.  But the "story" runs out almost instantly. The gameplay becomes a neverending stream of repetition after just a few hours. You can still progress your game, build more stuff, like better vehicles, farms, bases, defenses, etc. But it won't change the fact that at a certain point, nothing new happens. Not to mention, all this may be wasted when (if) the "chapter 2" update ever drops.
Because yes, that's the biggest issue with this game, the devs seem to post lots of fancy ideas in their devblogs, but the pace at which they are pushing updates is non-existant. The game was released back in 2016 and since then it did have a few minor QoL updates, but only 1! major gameplay update which introduced the "story mode".

The only thing that somewhat saves the game, are custom game modes (basically better versions of existing survival mode) made by tallented members of the community.

Is short:
If you want a game where you can just build wacky stuff and don't care too much about weird physics - Scrap Mechanic is totally servicable.
If you expect a story-rich survival experience - this is NOT the game for you. (and with dev's snail pace of updating, it won't be, for a very long time)

A Fun, Yet Ultimately Disappointing Experience

After spending considerable time in the world of 'Scrap Mechanic', a game that's been on the market for seven years, I find myself at a crossroads in terms of my recommendation. This title, at its core, is undeniably fun, especially when playing with friends. The collaborative elements and creative freedom offer an engaging experience that shines in multiplayer mode. However, this enjoyment is marred by significant drawbacks that cannot be overlooked.

One major issue is the story mode. Initially, it presents an intriguing concept filled with potential, but this quickly dissipates as you encounter its limitations. The deeper you delve into the structures and the world, the more apparent the game's unfinished nature becomes. Game breaking bugs are not just occasional annoyances; they are frequent enough to halt progress and diminish the overall experience.

Despite being in the market for several years, 'Scrap Mechanic' still feels like it's stuck in an early alpha stage. The lack of development progress is disheartening. It's as if the game has been abandoned by its developers, leaving a skeleton of what could have been a fully fleshed-out adventure. This sentiment is further exacerbated by the developers' habit of promising new content and updates, which, as time has shown, seem to be empty promises. This "carrot on the stick" approach does little more than build false hope among the player base.

It's a peculiar situation. On one hand, I thoroughly enjoyed the initial stages of the story mode and was genuinely excited about the potential 'Scrap Mechanic' had. There were moments of true enjoyment and creativity. However, after years of waiting for improvements and content that never materialized, my patience and enthusiasm have waned.

In conclusion, while 'Scrap Mechanic' can offer fun moments, especially in multiplayer, the myriad of issues, from game breaking bugs to unfulfilled developer promises, overshadow these positives. It's with a heavy heart that I find myself unable to recommend 'Scrap Mechanic'. The game, in its current state, is a shadow of what it could have been, and it's a disappointment to see such potential go to waste.

I absolutely adore this game and what it is but just a single issue breaks the entire game all on its own. The suspension glitch. This bug singlehandedly ruins the game for me, not being able to make suspension linkages or setups without stumbling upon this once. Double wishbone? It is magically stabilized which makes driving impossible, Macpherson? same issue here. Its like stumbling upon landmines where you have to try and avoid them but you just happen to be in Bosnia. I know the develelopers dont want to ruin old creations but for the love of god. Just make the old suspension legacy suspension or something and add in one which does not face this bug. All the old creations can keep the legacy one and we can use the one that works. Either that or add i a gyro of sorts because this bug makes the game not enjoyable at all. It does not help that the update is taking ages compared to expected release. Not reccomended unless developers decide to wake up.

From the moment I started building vehicles with intricate suspension systems, I found myself battling with glitches that rendered the suspension unpredictable and unreliable. The suspension glitches not only hinder the functionality of my creations but also make the gameplay feel inconsistent and, at times, downright aggravating. The lack of a quick and effective solution from the developers to address this issue is disappointing. It seems that despite numerous updates and patches, the suspension glitches remain an unresolved problem, leaving players like me with a sense of frustration and a growing dissatisfaction with the overall game experience. Furthermore, the glitches negatively impact the game's immersion and challenge. Instead of focusing on the creative aspects of building and problem solving, I find myself constantly battling against the erratic behavior of the suspension, which takes away from the joy of experimenting and perfecting my designs. While Scrap Mechanic has its merits in terms of creativity and engineering possibilities, the persistent suspension glitches have significantly tainted my overall perception of the game. Until this fundamental issue is properly addressed and resolved, I find it challenging to recommend Scrap Mechanic to others who may share my frustration with these persistent and disruptive glitches.

If you like building and survival games, and working out creative solutions to problems in the environment, then this is the game for you! 
If you are a casual solo player be warned, this is a more fun and painless experience with friends. The game  is quite difficult even on easy mode (for the survival game-type).


This game is a bit like Valheim and Sons of the Forest with it's survival mechanics (i.e manage your hunger, thirst & HP) and combat however the building is quite unique in this game as it mixes a cube/grid placement system with the freedom to use inventory items as well as building materials and built objects. 


I'll give it a score of 8/10, it loses 2 points because; 
there are 'quality of life' improvements that can be made to the building, general game-play, combat, physics and multiplayer connectivity. From what i have read, the development team has abandoned this game which is sad because it has a lot of potential and i feel that this game could do quite well in the current market of survival-builder games. The game looks a little 'janky'/unpolished when playing in 3rd person but otherwise if you play in 1st person the game looks amazing.

"Scrap Mechanic" has undergone a remarkable evolution since September 10, 2020, transforming from a promising sandbox game to an innovative platform bursting with creative possibilities. As someone who has been part of this journey, witnessing the game's evolution has been nothing short of impressive. The game's development strides since September 10, 2020, have been substantial. New features, enhancements, and updates have continuously expanded the game's potential, offering players an ever-expanding toolkit to unleash their creativity. One of the most striking changes I've observed is the introduction of a broader range of building components and tools. The developers have diligently added new parts, advanced mechanics, and refining existing features, empowering players to construct even more intricate and imaginative creations. Moreover, the game's optimization and performance enhancements have significantly improved gameplay stability, providing a smoother experience for players exploring the expansive worlds they craft. The addition of new game modes, challenges, and multiplayer functionalities has elevated the collaborative aspect of "Scrap Mechanic." The ability to share, collaborate, and compete within the game's community has expanded, fostering a vibrant and engaging environment for creators and players alike. The developers' commitment to listening to player feedback and implementing user-driven improvements has been a standout feature. It's evident that they've been dedicated to refining the game based on the community's input, resulting in a more fulfilling experience for everyone involved. While "Scrap Mechanic" has undergone substantial positive changes, there's still room for growth. The game's potential for further innovation and expansion remains vast, promising even more exciting updates and features on the horizon. In conclusion, the transformation of "Scrap Mechanic" since September 10, 2020, showcases a game that continually evolves and adapts to meet the desires of its community. Its commitment to creativity, innovation, and community-driven improvements makes it an ever-engaging sandbox experience that continues to captivate players who revel in building, inventing, and exploring within a dynamic and evolving world.

Pretty much every other review has said that witnessing a content update in this game is like finding an oasis in a desert, and it is, so I won't write something about it besides this, but there are other glaring issues in this game.

       In the current build of the game 0.6.6, there are performance issues that just make the game unplayable with advanced physics (also the only valid physics setting for anything). I would have said nothing about this if I was playing on a potato laptop with an Nvidia 1050 and some old Intel CPU, but I am instead playing with a Radeon 7900xt and  a Ryzen 7800x3d, both being high end, and nearly reaching the top in gaming performance. Now don't think that performance issues are going to be met all the time like on most new releases, but you will meet them and will be painfully obvious, be it a new complex build that makes extensive use of a lot of pistons, blocks hitting each other (frames drop whenever you are about to hit builds that aren't welded to the ground or on the lift, doesn't happen to small stuff, i.e blocks or just parts, but to bigger builds like vehicles, robots, anything that can move). Sure, maybe this is pretty hard to optimize, but consider this a warning if you will buy this game that big builds will set you in the single digits frames if they are about to hit another build. Sure it's in early access but that isn't an excuse for horrendous performance.

         Another problem you may encounter is doors not being able to close, simply why, it can fit inside the door frame, and it is one just stuck on the frame not closing, needing you to update the build's weight/mass (spray a block or remove/add one to it) to get the door closed, this I feel like it has something to deal with hitboxes because I get stuck sometimes to the wall whenever I am running alongside it. Maybe the door issue is on me and I suck at making working doors or the fucking hitboxes are made bigger than they seem (being 1 mm bigger in volume). A small inconvenience but one that occurs every time I close any door. (this happens to doors that use bearings, haven't encountered a problem when I was using a door based only on pistons). 

          Also outdated tiles that haven't been updated to use the trees that can be cut since survival launched. Very annoying cause those tiles look great and I want to cut those trees to be able to make a house in that area.
         Time for the small stuff, lack of proper console commands, being able to change gamemodes, i.e survival to creative and vice versa, would also love if we got a no clip gamemode which is creative but lets you clip  trough the walls.
          Now that I got over the bad parts of the game, here is the good stuff.
          
          This game has AMAZING community content, mods that give more blocks to build with, more interactive blocks to use and there also community made tiles and maps, there are also builds that have been uploaded to the workshop so you can mess around with them, take inspiration from them, (you can steal the logic systems from those builds have and use them for your own), of course you can also upload what you have made to the workshop. There are also mods that offer new content.

          Scrap Mechanic doesn't have the most jaw dropping graphics, but also doesn't have the worst ones, they are alright honestly.
          
            Creative with friends is nice, you can have a demolition derby by using cardboard or glass and some spud guns put on top of your car or some other spot, making it stand out, or just plain up build cardboard tanks and see who is the more skilled builder and driver/gunner

            Overall, if you don't care about getting content updates, buy the game while on sale, if you do care about the content updates, wait until this game finally gets that big content update and only after that should you consider buying it. 
            I want to add I haven't played most of survival as I haven't found it fun. Did play with a friend and the experience got better, but we haven't continued playing. Not the review to look for if you want something about survival.
            It sucks that the only game that has most of the freedom of Minecraft and has the technical aspects that allow you to make working vehicles and robots, is stuck in this cycle where we don't have any content updates  that I believe are needed for the game.

UPDATE (24/12/23):
Survival has released yay! The update was massively hyped and took forever but it added so much new content and changed the entire game. After the survival update dropped I personally was expecting that to be the end of waiting for updates, I figured they would happen much more often moving forward. Oh how I was wrong. The lack of updates makes it hard to keep playing the vanilla game, however hopefully when chapter 2 drops it will be awesome and won't disappoint. The best update so far in my opinion however is the addition of modding support, people can now add their own content, which to some degree makes up for the lack of vanilla content. I still recommend this game and think it is fun to mess around in, their are performance issues and issues surrounding their update schedule that need to be worked out but just looking at the game in its current state I definitely recommend it and I believe you'll enjoy what it has to offer.

Great game for anyone who wants to build something functional or realistic without to much hassle. It is easy to learn and its building mechanics are similar to Minecraft. 

Graphics and UI: It has a colourful art style that is consistent throughout the game and ok shadows making the game generally look great. The UI is clean and easy to navigate. The menu screen lets you build things in it's background making it very customisable. My only complaint is that the graphics are calculated on the menu screen so my computers fans run loudly even when I'm not playing the game. Overall- Great

Performance: Depending on your computer, the game can almost be unplayable at times. If I spawn in two slightly complex creations next to each other, My FPS drops to 20. You can turn down the physics quality but that makes any vehicle completely collapse in on itself. Overall- Bad

Updates: It only has one big update every 2-3 years because of the small number of developers. But, when the updates do come out, they are massive and completely change the game. Overall- Bad 

Creative Mode: You can create your own tiles or stick together the default ones to make any world you want. You can build with infinite resources and spawn in saved structures on a lift. Overall- Great

Challenge Mode: It has well designed levels that get progressively harder and introduce more game mechanics as you play. It also lets you easily download more community created levels so that you never run out of them. Overall- Great

Survival Mode: Similar to Minecraft's survival mode. Its well balanced but quite empty and unfinished at the moment. Its very fun and half of my playtime was spent playing survival. Overall- Great

Infinite Possibilities - Until You Hit the Skybox

TL;DR: The game is super glitchy. The physics are broken. It lags even on a fast computer when you make something even a little complicated. It freezes and crashes, sometimes the whole computer. Maybe good for messing around but serious gameplay is basically impossible.

So I got this game because my friends wanted to play it with me. I had fun making some cars and stuff but then I wanted to do something more ambitious. I tried to design a cannon using thrusters to propel a projectile. Problem is: the game's physics engine is EXTREMELY limiting.
Try to move something to fast? It will clip through and break. Try to spin something on a bearing fast? It will distort and probably break. Try to connect something (like a suspension spring) that's half-extended to another thing with the weld tool? Sorry. Want to control a piston to be able to stop at multiple points? no. Even when I used a popular glitch (potato guns shooting destructible blocks that transfer the momentum to the ammo) to design a gun, it would sometimes just explode or not shoot anything. I can't even aim it down, because when I try, the physics can't calculate the new angle and it just clips the ammo straight through the turret, exploding the whole thing! It's like a sandbox game, but creativity and complex design is just banned. Oh yeah, also it's super taxing on your computer. I have a ryzen 3700x (brand new with the motherboard as well!) and the game lags with just one of the glitchy tanks I made. The game also freezes and crashes. I'm making this review after the game crashed my whole computer (I had to reboot twice!). So unless you don't care about your computer killing itself, and only plan to make the most basic machines imaginable, this game will disappoint you.

While the updates have been very slow, I have a lot to praise about this game. 

The building mechanics are incredible with a physics system that is deep and robust. You can almost quite literally build anything that you can imagine. The limitless freedom with intense levels of potential creativity forge a wildly enjoyable experience. This applies to both Survival and Creative mode. Specifically, the functions of the pistons and bearings make for some incredible inventive opportunities. Combine that with the switches, controllers, and buttons to control your machinations down to the last block.

Being multiplayer is another gold star feature that should just be a baseline addition to any large scale game like this. Being able to goof around with friends and theory-craft off of each other in real time is absolutely phenomenal. It is also fair to mention that the multiplayer stability is fantastic, even with massive amalgamations of technology. 

The only cons I could see are that the game itself is very slowly paced in the beginning and that some people might not prefer the stylized art style. These are very much by design, so it boils down to personal preference in these situations. Aside from that, performance can be an issue with more "ambitious" builds. I would assume these are just technical limitations that will be addressed in the future, though.

As for improvements to the game itself, I do have a few suggestions. Large dedicated multiplayer servers would be one off the top of my head. More food recipes would make the early and late-game much more fulfilling/varied with the crops you have access to. Mob variety is big with me, but I understand that is the focus of the next large patch, so I won't linger on that notion. I would also like to see a larger variety of weapons, primarily the ability to use different melee style weapons aside from just the hammer.

All in all, I understand the lack of new content. As long as they work as hard as they have on this base game, we will see something that is more than worth the wait and that will be truly magical to experience.

Some people may say that survival won't come out and its a scam company, its not if you have payed attention recently. The game is also right now, (before update) still a very fun and playable game. If you are looking for a fun game that has building and soon pvp, pve and survival aspects, this is the game for you.

Edit:
So, it's been a few years, and even I must admit that this game is being developed at such a negligible pace, that well, it might as well not have a development team. However, I still keep my  review as positive, if you truly enjoy sandbox games Scrap Mechanic is still good fun, and it goes on sale every now and then for an even more fair price.

I enjoyed this game for a really long time,
it was fun to be able to build vehicles, structures, catapults, etc.

When survival mode was released I was excited, I enjoy the survival mode for some time, but then the excitement of things being new went away

It seems in the survival mode (at least for me) a lot more time is spent working to get more materials than having fun having fun building.
I tried a custom game mode call "less grind" which was fun.

Recently I tried making a catapult, and a projectile was launch downwards through the ground, what the game used to do when and object went through the ground was teleport the object up a the lowest height the object could be above the ground and not colliding with any other objects.

But I couldn't find the projectile, I tried riding a chair as it was launched through the ground after some time falling I was teleported high above the ground but the seat went missing.

To me it seem like the game removed the seat and the projectile, to me it seem the scrap mechanic devs changed the game to punish the player for exploiting the glitch, but to me it seems the game punishes the player just for encountering the glitch.

I think a lot of people have been asking for the game to be easier, and add things like, propellers, and wings, but the dev logs say that there going to add a lot of thing that will make it harder, like adding harder bots and making blocks flammable.

Materials being expensive and and blocks like wood being flammable does seem realistic to me, but quite a bit of realistic things aren't fun.

Scrap mechanic is a quite a unique game, I hope it becomes fun for me again, I don't know of a game that can replace it.

Abandoneware. The term used when a company completely gives up on a game without any communication towards the community. Scrap Mechanic is the perfect example of abandonware for anyone that wishes to study this phenomena. 

The only update this entire year wasn't actually an update at all, and was instead a message from whoever still has control of the Scrap Mechanic steam page about things that they are "working on". Nothing at all about anything stated is in the game or shows any sign of ever being implemented. The same is true for last year- simply stating "This would be cool if we put it in our game!" then radio silence for another year. There is currently no development on this game, there is no community communication about this game, there is no technical support for this game. For all intents and purposes Axolotl have literally forgotten this even exists- which considering this is their only game is quite confusing.

The game is a great concept with some good ideas that was abandoned years ago, yet still has the 'Early Access' tag so as to try and scam more people out of money thinking that any sort of development is happening (as is the entire point of Early Access)

Please understand this is not early access, it is dead. There is nothing new coming to this game, the game is dead. The game has not had anything done to it in years, and is not under any development because it is dead.

This game is dead abandonware and should have been removed from steam after a year with no contact from the devs, or at least had the 'Early Access' tag revoked.

Scrap Mechanic is an open-world multiplayer sandbox game developed and published by Axolot Games. The game was released in early access on January 20, 2016, and has since garnered a dedicated fanbase due to its unique blend of creative building, exploration, and survival elements. In this detailed review, I will explore the various aspects of Scrap Mechanic that contribute to its fun and engaging gameplay experience.

Scrap Mechanic places players in a post-apocalyptic world where they take on the role of a robotic mechanic, tasked with maintaining and building various contraptions to survive in the harsh environment. The game features a robust building system that allows players to create a wide range of vehicles, machines, and structures using a variety of parts and components. From simple cars and trucks to complex flying machines and automated farming systems, the only limit to what players can build is their imagination.

One of the most enjoyable aspects of Scrap Mechanic is the freedom it offers in terms of creativity and experimentation. Players can design and build their own custom vehicles and contraptions, testing and refining their creations to achieve optimal performance. The game's physics engine adds a layer of realism to the experience, as players must consider factors such as weight distribution, center of mass, and power output when designing their creations. This results in a deeply satisfying gameplay loop where players are constantly iterating on their designs to overcome challenges and improve their efficiency.

In addition to the building aspect, Scrap Mechanic features a vast open world for players to explore, filled with diverse biomes, resources, and hostile robotic enemies. The game encourages players to venture out into the world to scavenge for materials, discover new locations, and uncover the secrets of the game's lore. The sense of exploration is heightened by the game's day-night cycle and dynamic weather system, which adds an element of unpredictability to the environment.

Survival is also a key component of Scrap Mechanic, as players must manage their hunger, thirst, and health while navigating the world. This adds an additional layer of challenge and urgency to the gameplay, as players must balance their building and exploration activities with the need to gather resources and maintain their well-being. The game's survival mechanics are well-balanced, providing enough challenge to keep players engaged without feeling overly punishing.

Scrap Mechanic supports multiplayer gameplay, allowing players to collaborate with friends or strangers to build, explore, and survive together. The cooperative nature of the game opens up new possibilities for creativity, as players can pool their resources and expertise to tackle larger and more ambitious projects. Whether it's constructing a massive base, organizing a farming operation, or embarking on expeditions to distant biomes, the multiplayer aspect of Scrap Mechanic fosters a sense of camaraderie and teamwork among players.

Furthermore, the game has a vibrant and dedicated community that contributes to its ongoing success. Players frequently share their creations, mods, and gameplay experiences through online forums, social media, and content creation platforms. This exchange of ideas and resources enriches the overall experience of Scrap Mechanic, providing players with an endless stream of inspiration and new content to explore.

Visually, Scrap Mechanic features a charming and colorful art style that complements its lighthearted and playful tone. The game's environments are rich in detail, with each biome offering its own distinct aesthetic and atmosphere. From lush forests and rolling plains to desolate wastelands and industrial complexes, the world of Scrap Mechanic is a joy to behold and explore. The game's character and creature designs are equally endearing, adding personality and charm to the overall experience.

The sound design in Scrap Mechanic also deserves praise, as it effectively immerses players in the game's world. From the ambient sounds of nature to the clanking of machinery and the whirring of engines, the audio elements of the game enhance the sense of presence and engagement. The game's music further enhances the mood, with a dynamic soundtrack that adapts to the player's actions and surroundings, adding an extra layer of emotional resonance to the gameplay experience.

In conclusion, Scrap Mechanic offers a compelling and enjoyable gameplay experience that seamlessly blends creative building, exploration, and survival elements. The game's robust building mechanics, open-world environment, multiplayer capabilities, and charming visual and audio design all contribute to its appeal and longevity. Whether playing solo or with friends, Scrap Mechanic provides a wealth of opportunities for players to express their creativity, overcome challenges, and immerse themselves in a vibrant and dynamic world. With regular updates and a passionate community, Scrap Mechanic continues to evolve and expand, promising even more fun and excitement for players in the years to come.

I love this game, I've been playing it for a while but I've noticed a few things. In creative mode, there are several game breaking bugs that, for example, cause me to glitch out of the map, where there is no redundancy to protect from me going out of the wall or above the ceiling, causing me to lose hours of work as the ground has no collision outside of the wall. The creations that can be made using vanilla parts are rather primitive, so mods are a must for any moderately advanced logic systems if you would like them not to take a few years to process. The game is also not the best optimised and the physics engine has a few fatal errors, such as allowing fast enough objects to pass through walls. Overall a great game but I think the developers should focus on the bugs just as much as the main content.

[h1] Fun game or something more serious? [/h1]


Scrap Mechanic stands out as a true masterpiece in the world of sandbox gaming, where the possibilities for creativity seem boundless. As I delved into this pixelated universe, I quickly realized that it offers a challenge much more significant than initially anticipated. The game requires a level of skill and strategic thinking that adds a delightful layer of complexity to the experience. Building intricate machines and structures demands careful planning and problem-solving, making it a much more challenging but ultimately rewarding endeavor. Scrap Mechanic manages to strike a perfect balance between the freedom to unleash your imagination and the need for skillful execution, creating a gaming experience that is both stimulating and gratifying.

[h2] With what should you start? [/h2]

When you start playing Scrap Mechanic, it's a good idea to begin with Creative mode. In Creative mode, you have total freedom to be as creative as you want without any limits. You can try building different things, test out crazy ideas, and learn about all the different parts in the game.

Once you've had fun being creative, you can try playing in Survival mode. Survival mode makes the game more challenging. You'll need to collect resources, make things, and deal with a world that keeps changing. It's a bit harder than Creative mode.

The switch from Creative to Survival is like moving from practice to a real game. You use the skills you learned in Creative mode to tackle the tougher situations in Survival. Just know that Survival mode is tougher.

[h2] Story mode [/h2]

Scrap Mechanic plunges you into a colorful world where you, a skilled mechanic, land on a planet filled with malfunctioning Farmbots. Your mission: repair and maintain these robots while uncovering the mystery behind their chaos.

[i]For more information, please watch the video. [/i]
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=np4e2shI8nI&t=4s

[h3] Conclusion  [/h3]

In summary, Scrap Mechanic masterfully weaves creativity, challenges, and a captivating narrative. The transition from freeform building to strategic problem-solving adds intellectual depth, while the mission to save humanity. This game is great for smart people! It mixes imagination and skill, giving you a fun experience in a robotic world. If you like games that make you think and want something exciting, this one is highly recommended.

And lot of players have stopped playing the game because it's been in the early stages for a long time. Waiting for the full game can be tough and some people have gotten bored and left. It's important for the developers to make the game really good when it's finally ready so that players come back and stay.

UPDATE: The devs have ABANDONED this. They keep promising updates for years and, nothing. I do NOT recommend this anymore. Play Trailmakers because it's more polished and they continue to add more content.

The game is decent so far. The "mechanic" part of the game is pretty good if you're in creative because all the parts are available. So there's a lot of building and experimenting you can do. 

The problem for me is survival. I feel like the progression in the beginning is waaaaaaaay too slow and some things I have to look up because they're so hard to find. 

They really should take a page from BOTW because the progression is so natural in that game even without much explanation.

Fighting is a chore and clunky but absolutely necessary for progression. And, AFAIK, there is no way to upgrade your weapons to be more efficient in fighting. Baddies come after your crops every few minutes with no real explanation.

The creative part of the game is fun but in survival the progression is so slow that you won't be making anything decent for hours.

Hopefully, they work on the progression and make fighting a better experience because I don't feel like the fighting mechanic feels good or is fun.

This Review is Discussing this game as a Single player experience, I feel it's important to mention that. Which is why I am giving this a bad review. Creative mode is fun for a while though I can't vote for them as separate things. I would give a thumbs up to the creative mode.

               Is it just me or is this game really meant for just multiplayer? I have been around for a long time in this games development while putting in a lot of hours in creative. I drooled for survival before it came out and when it did it was a solo experience and... well, it was so much grind, with needing the food and protecting the farm and then hopefully killing bots to hopefully get component kits while also still trying to farm materials to build up defenses which are getting destroyed so you need more material. I like playing solo in a lot of these games since my friend group tends to be the Valorant types and I am not. I am glad for the mod integration so now I can put farms where ever, that by itself has helped putting farms out of reach, which still makes it difficult since getting water to it is a pain. This has lead to other noticeable things like balance issues in recipes, combat issues and hp values being static, RDM of the component kits (A SUPER ESSENTIAL THING USED IN A LOT OF RECIPES AND ALL UPGRADES) being dropped , and the scrap vehicle parts start with makes it worthless to try and use as a vehicle, it's not worth it. Sorry this is long winded and I hope the Dev team see it, I very much love your game but parts of it make me not want to play it. 
        I know this may not be my place but a couple of possible solutions: component kits as a recipe would be the biggest, willing to put the grind in to do that (within reason). Level ups in health or armor for your character, a magnet block or a connector dis-connector block that would help make tools easier a cool tool changer arm on a bot. The UV beds you are adding are very cool and would help a lot but it seems to then add another problem of adding yet another type of fuel on board or going through fuel faster and more component kits being gobbled up. 
      I remember earlier in the development you all asked for suggestions on what things you would like to see added.  I think i would have suggested different things seeing how survival turned out so far. Early game is still so grindy that it feels punishing. Thank you I am also leaving this as a review I realized as writing this is a good representation of my experience.

-Edit- So, I have close to another 100 hours. Whelp can't say anything has changed, I have to wonder what is going on? I have been watching twitter and... I don't know if anything in survival is going to get better, explosion bots, jumping bots, and climbing bots. Fire and underground stuff. Grreeaatt, I understand you are giving us a nice ability to grow things away  that shouldn't mean build 3 new bots to blow it all to hell. The turret looks cool, it looked cool a year ago. Climbing wheels made with goop awesome, how about anything to make early game marginally easier? How about ways to limit grinds? At this time I still only spend my time in creative because as a single player, survival isn't fun to me. I have seen YouTube video of people playing funny enough it usually starts after they have already progressed enough to have a defensible base and material to go do things. I wonder if that is due to the early game being just hitting trees over and over and over again... Anyway looking forward to the update hopefully this will fix things. (I am still hoping for a connector or magnet if nothing else just being able to pick up stuff with ma hands)

Creative Sandbox game with barebones survival gameplay. Development is very slow due to a small dev team.

Creative mode allows you to let your mind roam free, creating whatever mechanism floats your boat. Unless it's a plane. Scrap Mechanic has mod support and as such allows more creativity on that front as well. The learning curve for making good vehicles and creations is a rather steep curve I find, but if you stick with it it should get easier.

Survival mode allows you to get a basic feel for the game with an added survival mechanic and progression system. Farming plants and animals provides you with the food you need to survive, some of the materials you need to craft, along with plants to trade for useful tools. A challenging world enemy also exists that grants you access to a dungeon like area where you can receive the highest tier plants currently in game. Creativity is somewhat limited in this mode as you are limited by the resources required to create your vehicles/farms and upgrade the technological components within, such as your engine, or pistons. More is planned for the survival mode however, and in time things like a story and more progression will be added

Note; The survival mode hasn't been updated in quite some time.

Go read some of the Forum posts before buying this game. I didn't. 

In short it seems that this is one of those games that is ran by devs that are so incredibly slow with updates that the community gets upset each time between updates, with how long it takes for something meaningful to happen. 

It's a game, they should just admit is a bust, release as 'full' here and start work on another game. It's kind of like how 7 Days to Die has been in development early access for 7+ years now. There's a point of "Shit or get off the pot". 

I didn't enjoy my near 8 hours playing the game. The loop is not engaging. You have to destroy a specific mob literally HUNDREDS of times to get enough resources to do minor things. The robot you have to kill is not incredibly easy to kill, so you wind up spending a lot of extra time to kill them, where the other robot you get to take out is incredibly easy to the point of 'why exist?" 

 You have to travel for looooooong periods of time of just going straight to get middling resources.
'
It's not a good game. It needs a lot of QoL features, which aren't likely to show up for the foreseeable feature... which is meaning *YEARS*. Not months, not in a single year, but multiple years. 

This game is likely never going to be finished or ready to play. Unlike 7 Days to Die, which actually has a somewhat enjoyable game loop, even in its' incomplete state. 

This game ... was not fun. At no point did they let me make a machine to solve a problem. It was ALL... ALL manual to obtain resources. 8 hours in the only machine they allow you to make (via restricting resources) is a crappy car that is impossible to control because they give you not round wheels. 

Like this game's early game experience is a literal "fuck you' for anyone who isn't already sold into the late game. I didn't look into videos or anything, just bought the game because it looked good and is up my alley for style of games. 

So, you need to do your research to play this game. And that's not what I was looking for. I was hoping for a well developed game, not this trash.

The large majority of the scrap mechanic community has grown tired of the lack luster existence of developer communication and development headway. If the Dev(s) would communicate more frequently with the community about what is going on/ what the road map looks like/why content updates take so long, it would improve the interests within the community. I can respect that they have lives, like I have patients.. But from a business standpoint, they're community hype is dying and they're potential interests are decreasing for the lack of community management and content. 

 It's a excellent game idea, but it's only an "ok" game. The content just isn't as deep as it really should be, and the game can't handle multiplayer once everyone is actually underway with their own vehicles/to many moving parts/to many programed things have to be synchronized.

With the time they appear to be spending in hiatus, they probably could have made the game over in unreal engine 5. Let's all hope that, or something in response to the community is announced soon.

Something I fear.. 
This community is becoming a bit hostile, and rude.. 
When I read these rude things, it's apparent that they just don't have the patients to kindly ask the devs to not give up.
I do not want the devs to be discouraged, they don't deserve that. They deserve to handle the situation by the helm, and follow through with their dream. Develope the awesome game you set out to make.
I enjoyed my time playing your game, I just want more/better.
I will update my review accordingly.

WOW IT IS GOOD

Very neat game- lots of in depth mechanical parts and tons of ways to build ridiculously complex machines. Unfortunately I am far too stupid to even partially utilize the game's extensive mechanics. That's not the problem here though.

Survival mode is just... weird. You have to defend your crops from attacking robots, but exactly the way you go about that is not very intuitive. While resource gathering is REALLY cool, there's a lot of trial and error involved when it comes to base defense and the dodgy physics coupled with the insane potential complexity of your machines really only serves to build frustration as opposed to giving the player an opportunity to advance. Adventuring is fun but it's high risk and low reward.

The worst part is the fact that the game is, without question, dead in the water. I haven't played this game in like 4 years and yet I am absolutely certain the game hasn't changed. It's really a shame.

🛠️ Scrap Mechanic: Crafting Dreams and Contraptions in a DIY Wonderland 🤖

Scrap Mechanic isn't just a game; it's a whimsical realm where creativity reigns supreme, and ingenuity is your greatest tool. As someone who has always found joy in building and tinkering, Scrap Mechanic has become a personal haven where every nut and bolt holds the promise of ingenious contraptions and boundless possibilities.

Graphics and Aesthetics (4/5):
While Scrap Mechanic's graphics may not rival AAA titles, there's a charming simplicity that complements its DIY ethos. The blocky landscapes and quirky character designs contribute to an atmosphere that feels like a virtual workshop, inviting you to unleash your imagination.

Building and Crafting (5/5):
Scrap Mechanic's building mechanics are a playground for the inventive mind. Crafting vehicles, elaborate machinery, or even a whimsical flying machine is not just a task; it's a canvas for self-expression. The joy of seeing your creations come to life is a feeling that resonates with anyone who's ever marveled at their own handcrafted masterpieces.

Exploration and Adventure (4.5/5):
Venturing into Scrap Mechanic's vast world feels like stepping into an open workshop where creativity knows no bounds. The thrill of exploration isn't just about discovering new landscapes; it's about stumbling upon hidden treasures of inspiration that fuel your next ingenious creation.

Multiplayer Collaboration (5/5):
The multiplayer aspect of Scrap Mechanic is where the game truly shines. Collaborating with friends to build a colossal structure or designing intricate machinery together adds a layer of camaraderie that transforms the game into a shared canvas. The laughter that echoes in the virtual workshop becomes an integral part of the experience.

Challenges and Problem-Solving (4/5):
Scrap Mechanic isn't just about building; it's about overcoming challenges and solving intricate problems. The puzzles and obstacles scattered throughout the world aren't mere hurdles; they're invitations to showcase your engineering prowess and problem-solving skills—a satisfying experience for anyone who enjoys a mental workout.

Learning Curve and Accessibility (4/5):
While Scrap Mechanic is accessible to newcomers, the learning curve can be steep when diving into complex creations. However, this challenge is where the game's magic lies. The sense of accomplishment when you grasp advanced engineering concepts and create something truly unique adds a personal touch to the learning process.

Updates and Developer Engagement (4.5/5):
The dedication of the developers to Scrap Mechanic's ongoing improvement is evident in the regular updates and community engagement. It's not just about fixing bugs; it's about fostering a community of builders and dreamers—a sentiment that resonates deeply with those who appreciate a game that evolves alongside its players.

Conclusion (4.5/5):
Scrap Mechanic isn't just a game I play; it's a haven where my creativity takes flight and my imagination knows no bounds. It's not about achieving a high score; it's about crafting experiences, building dreams, and collaborating in a virtual workshop that feels like a second home. For anyone who sees beauty in bolts and artistry in engineering, Scrap Mechanic is a journey into a world where the only limit is your own creativity.

I've put a decent amount of hours into this game, and truly, there is so much I like about the game. The art style is fun. The way engineering is done, is simple and comprehensive. 

But the developers have all but abandoned it. Outside of one or two Twitter posts from time to time, showing "upcoming features" that never get released, the have been silent for more than a year.

Updates teased 5-6 years ago, still haven't been incorporated.

Lag issues when playing multiplayer are extreme. Even playing single player, frame rates take a massive dive with even fairly uncomplicated machines, and I'm running a pretty decent gaming rig. 

Certain physics issues that have been in the game since launch 7+ years ago, remain in the game. 

This follows the pattern from the game Raft, which had a lot of promise, updates early on...but the last few chapters came across rushed and disjointed. Then the devs have been completely silent about updates, fixes, etc. 

In short, I can't recommend a game from a company that does not follow through. 7 years in early access? No, that's development hell.

A very creative game with incredibly well done mechanics fueled by creativity crushed by lack of gameplay depth.

This game took a very large and needed leap by adding the survival mode, a mode in which you have gated progression and lack of resources slowing down your progression.
The issues with the survival mode are not immediately spotted but shortly after playing for several hours you notice the problems.

-Gated progression is a joke, the "gating" in this game consists of gathering some scrap metal and breaking burning trees around the crash site. Apart from this the only challenge you face is killing the enemies in the beginning of the game over and over for component kits as if you are trying to drop a high rarity item in an MMORPG, a very bad joke.
After this you can unlock almost any item available for crafting.

-Automation is nonexistent, for a building/tech based game you would expect at least some convenience while progressing and to offer the players the possibility of not repeating the same tasks they have been doing since the beginning of the game.
In this game however the devs thought it would be a good idea to give players mining drills to get metal quickly so they don't have to kill beginning mobs on hours end, but then decided to limit that to high quality metal only, so even when you have all the quality metal you need, because you don't have the god damn beginning rusty scrap metal, you are limited from crafting a relatively large portion of the crafting catalog.

The 90% of the value in this game resides in the creative mode where you can build whatever contraption or vehicle you want without being limited by the highly uncreative and uninspiring methods to farm resources while being offered no help in limiting the grind.
If you love building sandboxes or artificial difficulty to make the game seem like it has a lot more content than it shows, this is the game for you.

Very good

This game is more than a simple survival game! The creativity and dedication that you can put in your vehicles and machines is abnormal and very special compared to other survival games! You can make every Playthrough/World unique by trying out for example: a moving house, a raft or maybe a tower that has a very unreliable elevator that launches you so far up that you ragdoll of of it. In all seriousness tho, the amount of creative input in this game is quite limitless.
Combine that with the addition of multiplayer and Creative/Challenge mode and you got yourself a good time.

The Survival mode however can be grindy, but with it's great custom game support Scrap Mechanic got you covered, as there are many different Community created settings/mods that you can try out from Cheaper Recipes to New Explorable Tiles to literally a Raft like mod designed to change your complete workflow! So Community contributions make this game so much better and can improve your overall experience. Of course can you make them yourself too, although that gets a little bit more technical.

To summarize, I'd recommend this for everyone who enjoys being creative, likes a unique survival experience, wants to explore the depths that are community Challenges/Maps/Mods etc. or just wants to screw around with his/her friends!

Update: original review was 05.2020 and it's now 11.2023. What's changed for the review update? Well, actually, nothing changed at all since then. It's the same old story with no noteworthy game updates having happened in the past 2-3 years.

You can consider the game dead, get it on sale or on a key site. There are dev updates from the Baroque era on the game page but it's pretty unlikely any of that will actually make it into the game.

Speaking of which, the game itself seems interesting and I thoroughly enjoy building mechanical things with it and I'd love to play it some more, but...
--> Can't play offline (even single-player)
--> No updates at all. Survival launched 'as is' with a lot of stuff missing
--> Devblog 'content teasing' with nothing to actually show for it
--> Radio silence

Stay clear from this game if you:
- share your library (thus going offline) with virtually anyone
- want to play when there's no internet (train, uni, holiday, ...)

To clarify, you must be set to Online on Steam and have a stable internet connection in order to play Single Player, otherwise the game will not even start.
