Cons: survival mode:
Survival mode is unfinished and a grind just to play and the tutorial is not clear on things so if you’re here for a survival game, just don’t... unless you like grinding games
But if you’re here for the creative aspect then stay and read this

Cons: challenge mode:
The included challenge is not really clear when you get to at least 15 and more
Creating a challenge needs a lot of logic experience 
Community challenges are some times just tedious 

 Cons: creative mode:
Demolition derby’s or games where you destroy others don’t really work here

Pros: survival mode:
I can’t think of any but again I only got up to the end of the tutorial so idk

Pros: challenge mode:
There is a workshop for challenges
You can create your own challenges, 
You can send them to any friends who own this game

 Pros: creative mode:
You can play with your friends who own this game
You can do slip ‘n slide challenges with the low friction blocks
You can create boats with bubble blocks
You can find mods and creations on the workshop
You can build planes but need a mod to do that

Overall, if you want the survival aspect of it, just don’t pls
But If you want the creative aspect then this is a good game for that

Old review from years ago:

Fantastic game but the fundamental code design seems incompatible with complicated machines or multiplayer that is performance friendly.

The setting, gameplay, and creative options are all top notch. It's easy to execute your ideas and have them work predictably. I would also describe the current state of survival to be incomplete. There's enough here to enjoy for many hours but it is obvious that the world is missing key elements and polish. 

I found few to no bugs during my 100 hours of playing, which is impressive, but I would like to see improvements made to performance when creations scale up or become more numerous in a server. The game has 9 or so physics settings so you can improve performance, but the simple settings do not simulate mechanical systems effectively so once you turn down physics, expect better performance at the cost of having your vehicles unable to drive or move correctly. I found the 'introducing the controller' video to be somewhat disingenuous for this reason, as most of the creations showcased would not run at even 30 fps on a decent gaming rig.

I highly recommend this game, but expect your creations and your multiplayer lobbies to remain small in scale.

TL;DR: this game's multiplayer SUCKS. You won't be having too much fun playing over the net. And there is no LAN mode.
I have 1Gb ethernet, on average 800Mb. My friend has 140Mb on average, also on ethernet. We play on survival with hardly any player creations and I'm the host, using an alright PC, i3 9100F, which, although not great, is not even 60% used. Also, I'm running 42GB ram, got >100GB of free space on my nvme SSD, I have a 3060 with 12GB of VRAM. It certainly isn't my PC being shit. He has 42 GB of ram too, gtx 1660, i9 10gen, and in singleplayer there are absolutely no issues. Oh, forgot to mention, we live in the same city, too, so its not "ThE uNdErWaTeR cAbLeS" doing all that. And in valorant, playing on server that are based in our city, i have <2 ping and my friend has usually <15. In scrap, creative multiplayer all works well. Its only in survival that he has any lags. My character, on his screen, is all good, no desync, but the vehicles lag horribly. And its not our fault. I hope survival gets optimized next update. Scrap Mechanic is a survival sandbox game in which you can build all sorts of machines.
[h1]Similar games:[/h1]
Minecraft, Space Engineers, Trailmakers, Terratech
[h1]Pros and cons:[/h1]
+ pretty graphics
+ a lot of possibilities
+ workshop and mods (community)
- symmetry
- bugs
- rare updates
- a lot of missing features
[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
A game with a lot of possibilities and a giant potential, unfortunately with a lot of issues that stop it from becoming what it could be.

"Scrap Mechanic" is a delightful computer game that unleashes the inner engineer and creative genius in players. This sandbox building and survival game presents a charming world where players can construct, tinker, and experiment with a wide array of mechanical devices and contraptions.

The graphics in "Scrap Mechanic" are simple yet charming, featuring a colorful, blocky aesthetic reminiscent of childhood building toys. The vibrant world is inviting and encourages players to dive into a playground of engineering possibilities.

The gameplay is where "Scrap Mechanic" truly excels. Players gather resources, design intricate machines, vehicles, and structures, and navigate through challenges using their mechanical creations. The physics engine adds an extra layer of realism and complexity to the game, making it incredibly satisfying to see your inventions come to life and function as intended.

One of the game's standout features is its emphasis on cooperative play. Players can team up with friends to collaborate on building ambitious projects, fostering creativity and fostering a sense of teamwork.

However, a slight drawback can be the learning curve for new players. The game offers a plethora of tools and components, and understanding their functionalities and how to combine them effectively may take some time and experimentation.

In conclusion, "Scrap Mechanic" is a captivating experience for those who enjoy building and engineering. Its creative potential, cooperative gameplay, and the joy of watching your mechanical marvels in action make it an excellent choice for both aspiring and seasoned inventors.

Caveat at the start:
If the rating system were more refined, and a positive is a 7/10 or better, I would put this game around a 5 or 6 out of 10. 

The general gameplay loop is good. Collect, farm, defend the farm, iterate on your creations, repeat. I definitely enjoyed my time playing the game, especially with my 2 friends, as evidence by the 125 hours I sunk into it on the multi-player world & my solo world. There is a learning curve, in how to properly build machines for your play style, and the building system is pretty good. It has its quirks, but all "engineer" games do. 

The problem stems from longevity, grind, and development timeframes.

Grind: 
In order to upgrade your machines you need component kits. To get component kits you need to go out and clear randomly generated structures to loot the chests & kill bots. The problem comes from the drop rate of the kits & the quantity needed for each mechanism, and them not being retrievable once you install them in a mechanism. Couple this with the stack limit of 10, and a small inventory you have to do a lot of go out, clear a structure or 3, return to base to offload materials then repeat the trip. 
You can avoid some of that by putting chests on your vehicle, but rapidly you will clear out the near POI's and they take a long time to regen, so you have to go further out to get more of these kits. 

Longevity:
The next big issue is the optimization in the game is... lackluster. If you play anything like me or the 2 friends I played with your machines will get complicated, and the more moving parts your machine has, the worse the game runs. 

Before we stopped playing, my machine, if it wasn't welded to the ground would halve the framerate & "tick"speed of the game, while the more advanced machine my friend made would cut it down by 75% or so. 

Because of this, making a jack of all trades machine is actually not good because of the performance impact it gives. Which means you need to make more, smaller vehicles to specialize in one small task. 
This goes back to the grind problem, as you need component kits for pretty much every important mechanism.

Development Timeframes:
The devs definitely like this game, and the companion game Raft. The problem with scrap mechanic update schedule stems from a couple of known reasons, and a few I will guess at. 
The known reasons are the dev team split their attention and started other projects before finishing this one, which is fine I applaud them for doing so especially since both games are good. The real issue seems to come from what I call "goal bloat" (there is a correct term, I am just forgetting it at the moment). 

Goal bloat is what the big problem right now is. They released the initial version of Survival (the main game) back in mid 2020. They announced Survival update 2 back towards the end of 2020. Each devblog since they had added additional new goals that push the update back. Do not get me wrong, new content, thoroughly tested is very very good. The problem comes from they should have split chapter 2 into multiple parts, or heck just make each successive update the next chapter. The reason I consider this to be the biggest downfall of the game right now is one of the biggest features of chapter 2 is heavy optimization improvements to the engine and how physics calculations are done, which in turn will greatly affect creations & complexity "limits" the game currently has. 

If the dev team had split chapter 2 into smaller segments, rather than let goal bloat delay the update by 2 full years at this point I would not have these criticisms, as the promised optimization would probably have solved most of them. 

All that said, if chapter 2 includes all the stuff they promised, it works well, and optimization allows for more build freedom & complexity, I think it will be worth the wait. 


TLDR: 
Game is good, can get grindy, complex machines or additional physics calculations bog the game down a fair amount. Necessary optimization has been pushed back for approx 2 full years due to shifting goalposts with chapter 2 (next major update) due to the development team adding more content than initially announced / expected.

The game is great.  Except for the horrible lag.  It's damn near impossible to play.  I play with 2 others, some days, we just rubberband around the game.  Get a little frustrated, maybe die.  Other days, we can move, but the game doesn't register our last action for, say eating or drinking, or sitting in a vehicle, or placing an item, at least 1-2 minutes.  Before you say, did you check your connections or did you see if you were capable to play it on your machine, yes.  We checked.  We had each host a game and same issues all around.  If they could fix the lag problems, it would be an awesome game!  Even with the lack of content at this moment in the development.


Edit:  It has been awhile.  I'm writing this after adding 1000 hours.  The game has gotten better.  Slightly.  Lots of mods to help change it up while we wait for Chapter 2.  I still enjoy creating bases and mobile creations and machines for all sorts of stuff.  If I were to rate it out of five for the first review, it would have been a 2 out of 5, now I would push it to 3.5 out of 5.  Still waiting for Chapter 2 and full release.

Scrap Mechanic Is an exceptional game about crafting, being creative and having fun with Friends, but there is unfortunately two sides to it which is not often spoken about.

The first side is the good side revolving around the Creative and Challenge Modes. They are phenomenal and they allow you to invent some of the most insanely awesome and innovative creations that you can think of. Vehicles, Houses, Games and All sorts of other things which can easily keep you entertained for hundreds of hours if you're the creative type of person. Plus you also have the steam workshop where you can try out other peoples ideas and even test cool mods if you're up for it, however this is basically where the fun sadly ends.

Now for the bad side. I know some people will feel differently than me on this, but Scrap Mechanic has been out for a long time, and the game has always revolved around having fun with your friends and being creative, Then one of the most anticipated features finally came to the game in the first half of 2020 and that was the Survival mode which a lot of people including myself were looking forward to. When you watch the trailer everything looks fun, but i promise you it wears off quite quickly, especially if you are not new to this game. The survival mode is basically the same as Creative, but the world looks better, and you have to keep yourself fed and hydrated as well as grind for any form of resources, That's it. There is nothing nice and fancy about the survival mode and To be honest the Developers enjoy Teasing the players with their Devblog's showcasing all the new features that they're working on, but unfortunately they have only made two updates to their survival mode in the last almost 3 and a half years.
To Add to that, the survival mode makes crafting a very tedious task, and nor do they entertain you with any ounce of a story. Let me show you what i mean:

Survival Mode Features:
- Player needs to be fed and hydrated, else they die.
- Player has to farm a ridiculous amount of resources in order to build anything that actually can be durable enough against 
  the enemy bots.
- There are no Story elements yet, Just a logbook, that's it.
The general gameplay of survival goes like this: 
Gather and farm crops (crops are used as currency), Don't die to the bots whom continuously raid your base for the crops. Once the Crops have been harvested, sell them to a farmer NPC to get ammo and or weapons and or food. Take what you have earned and repeat the cycle. This is survival, nothing more and nothing less.

The game has so much grinding on survival with so many features that have been left out which apparently is still being worked on, so if you are going to buy this game, Please do not do it thinking that the Survival mode is complete or even close to completion. DO NOT buy this game if you are looking for a story because you will not find it at this moment. Please do not misunderstand what i am saying in this review as i have enjoyed this game for a long time as i would play it for many hours on a friends account, and the creative and challenge modes are worth every penny, but the survival mode is honestly not worth purchasing at this moment.

So in a nutshell, be sure to buy this game only if you are happy playing a currently incomplete survival mode or if you want to build tons of cool stuff in creative. If you are wanting a story then you wont find it at this moment, and the developers haven't specified when their next update will arrive, but one thing i can tell you is that it has been over 1 year since their last survival update and it can easily be another one or two years before the next update is released.

If you can't tell by how many hours I have in it, I absolutely love this game. Have had it since around 2016 and it's been amazing to watch the game progress over that time. I enjoy the creative mode a lot, as it has a lot of community content and is all around just fun to mess around with. However, survival is where this game truly shines. It has a super satisfying gameplay loop, in particular with farming (although grinding for component kits can be tedious). Exploration is a ton of fun, unlocking cosmetics is a cool reward, the "combat system" (if you even want to call it that, it's just hitting things lol) is simple but enjoyable, and building complex creations to more efficiently harvest resources is both fun to do and rewarding to complete.

It's super addicting, and although new content comes out infrequently, there's loads when it does. (And it's all of super high quality, with not a microtransaction in sight!)
Not to mention the beautiful art style and great music.

TLDR: Fantastic game with a super addicting gameplay loop and loads of character. Completely and totally worth $20.

Scrap Mechanic is a fantastic game for those who love creative building and making super fast cars. The building mechanics are intuitive and enjoyable, allowing you to let your imagination run wild. I've created numerous designs and shared them on the workshop for others to enjoy.

While I personally don't care for the survival or challenge mode, the building aspect alone keeps me engaged and entertained. The ability to construct various vehicles and see them come to life is incredibly satisfying. The game offers a wide range of parts and tools to experiment with, giving endless possibilities for creations.

The community aspect is also a highlight, as you can easily browse and download creations from other players. It's a great way to get inspired and see what others have come up with.

Overall, Scrap Mechanic is a must-play for creative minds who enjoy building and designing. Whether you're into survival challenges or simply want to unleash your creativity, this game offers hours of fun. Give it a try and let your imagination soar!

"Scrap Mechanic" is a creative building and survival game developed and published by Axolot Games. Players struggle against enemies and adversity as they build vehicles, machines and structures using a variety of materials.

Creative Construction Mechanics: The game offers players a wide range of materials. Using these materials, you can design your own vehicles, machines and structures.

Dynamic Physics: The game's dynamic physics engine ensures that the vehicles and structures players build behave realistically.

Survival and Exploration: The game includes survival and exploration. Players collect food and resources while fighting against enemies.

Multiplayer Mode: "Scrap Mechanic" offers the ability to play online with friends or other players. You can have fun experiences by co-operating or competing together.

Graphics and Style: The game is characterised by bright and colourful graphics. Creative design and a humorous style set the atmosphere of the game.

Community and Mods: The game has a large mod community. Mods can add new content, tools and mechanics to the game.

Community and Reviews: "Scrap Mechanic" is popular with players who love creative building and exploration. The game's freedom of creativity, dynamic physics mechanics and multiplayer options have received positive reviews.

Development and Publisher: Axolot Games is the developer and publisher of the game. The game is supported by regular updates.

Conclusion: "Scrap Mechanic" is a fun game that combines creative building and survival mechanics. Building vehicles, machines and structures using materials offers players a creative experience. If you are looking for a game where you can use your creativity and co-operate with your friends, "Scrap Mechanic" may be an interesting option for you. By checking out the game's community and reviews, you can evaluate whether the game is suitable for you.

Very good game, take this recipe for Finnish Karelian Pie for when you wait for survival chapter 2.

Crust dough:
1½ dl water
1 tablespoon of oil
3/4 teaspoon salt
3 dl rye flour
1 dl wheat flour

Filling option 1:
2 ½ dl water
2 dl of rice
7 ½ dl of milk
1/2 teaspoon salt
1 egg

Filling option 2:
8 dl of water
2 dl of rice
2 dl (lactose-free) cooking cream 10% or 15%
1 egg

Filling option 3:

2 dl of water
2 dl of pre-ripened, whole barley groats
1.5 l of milk
1 teaspoon of salt
1 egg

For greasing: melted butter and water

First prepare the filling:

Preparation of filling option 1 and 3:
2. Mix rice or barley in boiling water and boil for 10 minutes.
3. Add milk and let the porridge slowly boil for 30 minutes, stirring occasionally along the bottom. Leave the filling to simmer under the lid for 10 minutes.
4. Season the finished porridge with salt and cool it.
5. Mix an egg into the cooled porridge.

Preparation of filling option 2:
2. Mix rice with boiling water and cook for about 30 minutes. Stir occasionally.
3. Add (lactose-free) cooking cream and salt. Let the porridge simmer for about 10 minutes.
4. Pour the porridge into a flat container and pour a splash of cold water over it so that a crust does not form on the surface of the porridge.
5. Mix an egg into the cooled porridge.

Making the pies:
1. Mix cold water, oil, salt and flour with a wooden fork. Knead the dough until smooth and firm.
2. Sprinkle a mixture of rye and wheat flour on the table and pour the dough on top of the flour. Roll out the dough into a disc about 1/2 cm thick.
3. Press poop from the plate with a drinking glass.
4. Place the poops in stacks of six so they don't dry out. Cover the stacks with a plastic bag or bowl.
5. Use a rolling pin to roll the dumplings into thin round or oval shells. Stack the shells on top of each other and sprinkle rye flour in between. Cover the peel stacks with a plastic bag. Fill the shells as soon as possible so they don't stick to each other.
6. Take the crusts on the baking table, spread a spoonful of filling in the center of the crust (1 cm thick layer of filling) and leave about 1 cm of empty space on the edges of the crust.
7. Fold the opposite edges over the filling and crease the pies with your index fingers.
8. Transfer the pies to a baking sheet on baking paper.
9. Bake pies at 275-300°C for about 15 minutes.
10. Grease the pies with melted butter mixed with a splash of water.
11. Stack the hot pies in a bowl on top of each other and cover with baking paper and a cloth. Serve with traditional or egg-free egg butter.

Traditional egg butter

4 eggs
2 dl cottage cheese
100 g of butter or margarine
(4 tablespoons chopped parsley)

Put the eggs in a pot of boiling water one by one using a tablespoon and cook for 8 minutes.
Put the boiled eggs in cold water for a while, so the shell comes off easier.
When the eggs have cooled, peel them.
Put the eggs on a large plate and chop them with a fork or use an egg cutter.
Mix in cottage cheese and room temperature, soft fat.
If you want, you can add chopped parsley on top.
Eggless egg butter

1 tsp pre-cooked chickpeas
250 g firm tofu
150 g of margarine
1 teaspoon of salt

1 dl parsley and 1 chili

Drain and rinse the chickpeas. Roughly mash the chickpeas with a fork.
Crumble the tofu.
Mix chickpea and tofu crumbs and margarine. Season with salt.
Chop the parsley and mix in. Also chop half of the chili and mix in. Garnish with chili slices.

The game is nice and could be better, but there hasn't been a story content update in three years or so. The last two major updates were 'Challenge Mode' and 'Creative Mode' - both of which do nothing for me. Instead, we get teased a lot of really cool features that, once released, will most likely cause the player to lose their progress and create a new world. This isn't an issue, since its an Early Access game. But, it would be nice to have some incremental updates so that we could enjoy these cool features.

Being an EA game, most devs showcase content that will be released in the near future, not years down the line. Due to what seems to be an evolving scope creep, you are basically paying to play a demo while you wait for the full release. The devs don't give much in the way of developmental updates, and the only reason it doesn't seem abandoned is because it sold so many copies they should have plenty of revenue to continue development.
But, with the features they've shown, there better be a plethora of content they've kept secret - because there's no way it should be taking this long to release what they've showcased...unless they're just sitting on their thumbs and enjoying the payday they got from sales, deciding to develop down the scenic route.

The gameplay is fun and there are tens of hours of content, depending on how deep you want to play. Some of this playtime will be a grind that's not as painful as other games. There are players with hundreds and a thousand plus hours - i'm sure creative mode and steam workshop helps with those numbers. But, this game will be a lot better once its released and you can count on your game not being wiped or having to rely on inconsiderate developers to supply additional content.

i definitely do not recommend this game, based on the route development is going. But, if you are enticed by the steam page, the videos, and don't mind potential world wipes, long waits for content, or a potentially abandoned game due to the typical EA, 'family / personal / health / team moving on / insert most used excuse here' issues outcome, then it's worth a purchase. Plus, its been nearly three years. Unless it gets abandoned, your wait will be significantly less than others.

[h1] Edit - August 25th 2023 [/h1]

The game has not changed at all, the steady development I praised 3 years ago is nowhere to be seen. Survival is STILL in no playable state, at this point it is ridiculous, pointless robots are being added / teasered but no core game mechanics whatsoever are added to the survival mode. The last major update this year was for the challenge mode, which came after the survival mode and I feel like no one asked for the update. What people have been asking for is a playable co-op survival mode, which is nowhere in sight after [b] 3 years [/b] of active development.
Ultimately I had to change my review to not recommend.

[h1] Steady development, worth supporting and waiting for [/h1]

Most people are a bit hesitant when it comes to invest money in early access games, since developers often lose their goal / motivation and the desired outcome isn't met. Not the case here.
The delevopers are very passionate and are non stop working. While they keep you waiting and making you unpatient, they're always sooner or later delivering an update you've been long waiting for.

I've had this game before any signs of a survival mode and now I'm insanely happy it has been published. While it still has some flaws (for god's sake add a map, please) it's a pleasure observing the changes this game goes through. Survival is already fun to play, even so more with friends!
While this game is more of built to let you build dynamic stuff like vehicles, they're also working on static stuff, so you're able to build houses etc. At least it's more optimized than it was in the beginning.

All in all I'd say give it some time, support it and come back to a wonderful game.
You already can have fun right now in creative mode, creating a new project with friends. Can't wait for the final product.

Game is completely inconsistent and really, not much fun at all. Full of bugs, whether it's blocks not registering placement properly or random massive spikes in memory and GPU usage. Not to mention, sometimes placing blocks can result in them being placed outside the terrain and irretrievable. Really, really annoying when those blocks are something you've worked for hours to collect and refine. Additionally, the devs have neglected basic combat improvement ideas from the community for years. This one's a hard pass.

I love Scrap Mechanic. It has certainly carved out its niche among engineering games, offering a higher level of complexity than something like Trailmakers, but is easier to learn and master than something like Stormworks. Its art style, its visuals, its endless replay ability are all elements that make it a truly special game, but the lack of support from the devs, the bugs and the gaps between major updates make it game that I wouldn't recommend buying. The devs have seemed to all but abandoned this game, that last update happening in June of 2022 (at the time of writing). Game breaking bugs, performance issues and a general lack of story in survival mode make the lack of updates particularly egregious. To sum up, dont buy the game, unless you want to wait years in between updates and are fine with the perpetual early access state.

Buy if you like making contraptions; this game is not as complicated as you may think. It's very easy to make a car.

This game (while having some physics glitches) provides a very good way to build random moving contraptions. The game does not limit your creativity by limiting the complexity of your vehicles (Which could be seen as a bad thing but I like it). The workshop has a constantly expanding wide range of creations that you can play with or take inspiration from for your own creations. I've never played multiplayer so I don't know what it's like. The game can have some lag issues with buildings but if you weld the creation to the world it should be fine. However bearings, a part which is used in almost every build, could be better optimised.
Didn't expect to construct a turing complete computer when I purchased the game.

Hola!

So, Scrap Mechanic, huh, crazy game, Scrap mechanic is a fun sandbox to let you express your creativity and go wild, with it's nice and snuggly building system you will be making stuff from cars to bikes to planes, to working calculators and hover-tanks with practice.
Mods are a massive part of scrap mechanic too, they really improve the experience in my opinion, but learn the game normally before delving into the steam workshop.

Scrap mechanic also has two other modes if doing anything you want isn't up your alley:

SURVIVAL: an extensive survival game that has all the great features of scrap mechanic, build bases, set up traps, create cars to transport fruit to sell, explore giant warehouse dungeons, all while defending your farm against the enemy farmbot hordes!

CHALLENGE MODE: challenge mode lets you put your building skills to the test, learn to create wall crawlers, ball carriers, and just a fast car with limited resources, there are also custom challenge trials that can be created, downloaded and played via the workshop.

Plus, if that wasn't enough (how?) custom games can be made within and downloaded.

I'd say scrap mechanic is pretty worth it! Of course, the game is in early access and survival is not finished fully, but what we have now is great, and it can only get better from here.

Mechanic, but Scrap

     I write this review for the 0.6.5 version of the game, after the Survival update, but before the Survival: Chapter 2 update. Instead of outright praising or disparaging the game like so many other reviews would do, I want to share one of my favorite experiences with the game.
     Before I do that, there are some bits of information I'd like to get out there. On the one hand, I'd like to contextualize the story so that you understand, but on the other, I want to help you avoid it in-case the question of "should I purchase this product" can be solved by explaining the core principles of the game.
     The game currently has four modes (Challenge, Survival, Creative, and Custom Game), which all revolve around the building mechanics. You will be building a lot in pretty much every mode (except maybe Custom Game, which is player-generated content).
     The story I'm going to share comes from my time in Survival Mode, which currently has very little content. There are three things that you can do: collecting materials to build vehicles and bases, farming to buy new stuff and to eat, and going through unforgiving warehouses full of robots to reap decent(-ish) rewards. There is no story, so it is essentially a sand-box where you can do anything that you feel like doing, except you can starve or be bludgeoned to death by hay-wire... hay-bailing bots.

This should be enough information for me to start my story.
     I was on an excursion to find an oil source. It is pretty tedious to jump into the ocean looking for oil deposits, so I was looking for a lake that give me an infinite amount of fuel. I was at the far reaches of the map which is (surrounded by ocean). I was between a forest and the ocean, which gave me just enough room for my exploration vehicle to fit on the beach between them. While I was out chopping down trees, I was ambushed by two Farmbots (the big red bois). I drove part-way into the sea while I was trying to escape, and that's when my car was promptly diced into pieces. While I was able to jump on a rock in the ocean, taking the ruin of my vehicle with me safely, I had lost two vital parts: one of my wheels and my Driver's Seat. My only Driver's Seat. Without the Driver's Seat, there is no way to steer my vehicle, and no way to stop me from falling out. What made things even worse is that my vehicle was carrying chests which I filled with hours of gathered materials (hint: that is a bad idea), some VERY difficult to obtain (including some stuff from a few Warehouses), and I did not want to part with them if I could avoid it. That meant that if I died, or if my chests or any more parts were broken, I'd have to forsake those materials and all of the progress I made. There was a lot at stake, more than in any other game I've played, and it was completely caused by me. I really like how, even though there isn't a lot of content in Survival, the game mechanics interact with each-other in a way that rewards and punishes my actions in a very natural way.
     What I ended up doing was taking the blocks that I had to create a make-shift cockpit, and then I created a trike. I placed the engine where I could see it, and then I took off.
     After sliding past the Farmbots (which were trying to shoot me with poison from the ocean floor), I was able to start heading back in the dead of night. While I was making my way back, a group of four or more Haybots (hay-bailing robots) were chasing me, and I wasn't able to go full speed or there was a risk of me falling out. I had to constantly monitor the robots chasing me, the balance of my vehicle to avoid tipping, and where I was going to not run into anything. I kept on using the lift to reposition my vehicle (as I had no steering). Then a Farmbot noticed me. Farmbots are much faster than Haybots, which meant that I had to up the speed on my craft a considerable amount just to keep pace with it. My vehicle, as I expected, tipped over, and tumbled down a big hill still with the robots in hot pursuit. I was barely able to get my vehicle on and off the lift before the Farmbot caught me: I saw it swing its scythe, I was that close.
     I eventually escaped their pursuit, and in an additional thirty minutes of meticulously positioning my vehicle and handling its acceleration, I arrived at my base. The sense of relief I felt coming back to the base was one of the most rewarding feelings that I have had in a game. I almost felt the "you got back home" feeling, even though my base is literally just four metal walls. While I was objectively worse off than I was before, having lost some progress on my upgraded seat and still not having located an oil pond, I was able to take a challenging scenario with limited resources and make it back without losing more.

There's my story.
     I could not recommend this game to everyone I met. Not everyone has the motivation to make fun experiences, and even people who are inspired to play with a game's systems may not like the systems present in this game. This game is by no means centered around its story, but rather the systems with which the player can interact. At the end of the day, I'd argue that most people aren't going to be as interested in a building sandbox as I am. However, if you are part of the developer's target audience, this may become your favorite game as it has become mine. I hope this has helped you in some way.

Fantastic Game! Instantly recommended!
I watched a video on this game the other day and I was intrigued. After doing a bit of research (looking in the comments) I found out that it was this game. So far I've only done the challenges and creative so as to get a feel of the games mechanics.
So far here are my finding. Firstly there is a steep learning curve, as the mechanics of building do take some time to get used to, particularly in regards to vehicles. However, after figuring that out (the challenges were a great help as they are more akin to tutorials!) Vehicle construction was a breeze. I haven't gotten to the survival part of the game yet but I imagine that it'll be extraordinarily fun.
A quick note though, flying is incredibly difficult (makes sense considering you have to think 3 dimensionally in construction and flight.)
Edit: I've now been playing this game for a total of 29 hours and it's still loads of fun. Since my original posting I've delved into the realm of survival and it is amazing. I've yet to build a base but i'm holed up in a mechanics station. I've build vehicles that I otherwise wouldn't have built and I've gotten pretty good at bopping farm bots over the head.

This game was "released" in EA in 2016 - 6 years ago, and it's still in EA.  I guess that's fine.

My gripe is that it won't support left-handed, when this is a trivial thing to fix.  Have the game read the OS settings for the mouse keys.  They have a keybinds.json file, but that doesn't fix the problem when I edit it as some people have claimed it should be edited.  But who cares?  Just use the OS settings like you were supposed to.

UPDATE: It's even worse than that - when I used VoiceAttack to change my mouse settings as a macro (it just openned the mouse settings and flipped the left to right or right to left - no magic here), the game remained unchanged!  It still forces me to use the other mouse button regardless of what Windows has set up as my active mouse button.  This really stinks!

Now you would think "no big deal".  But that's because you're right-handed, so you never run into this.  I find it enormously frustrating that games ignore left-handed people.  But they are relatively rare - most games get it right.

If I could refund this I would... I think this is what I noticed when I first bought the game, and I haven't touched it in years, and it's still as bad as it was when I first tried it.

Amazing game, I have spent way too many hours in this game but I have enjoyed every single one of them. When I'm bored I often just start this game and keep improving one of my flying machines or build some random idea that I had. This is the best 20€ I have ever spent in my life. (My mom bought it for me but you understand what I mean.) You can build whatever you want in this game.

The only thing that is not very good in this game is the water physics. To make something float you need to add bubble plastic, the more bubble plastic you add to your creation the more it will float. It's just not a very good system because most of the boat will just consist of bubble plastic. In real boats you can use that space for other things like kitchen, beds etc. In this game you cant because the entire boat is filled with bubble plastic.

Also there is no aerodynamics in this game. You build flying machines with thrusters instead. But there is countless mods that improve this game. Like with aerodynamics.

I've had 2 saves in survival ruined. One was when I got killed by a robot. Apparently I was too close to a static structure and my loot bag clipped through the wall and I couldn't get it. It had around 5 hours of gathered materials in the bag. So I decided to start a new save since I had to grind for the materials anyway and wanted to get a new world gen. The second time I got reset was when I got raided for farming, as you do in this game. The robots came to raid my farm and I killed most of them only to find one of the little robots near my crafting robot 5 minutes later. The Rat bas***d destroyed a large chest with crafting materials in it and 10 hours of grinding just evaporated along with all my food stores. Sure, I get its a survival game and I probably should have been more careful about where I was placing things and built a protective shelter but its very bad game design to just delete hours worth of progress for something like not noticing a rogue robot in the far end of my base just wreaking havoc. Perhaps just drop the contents of the chest on the floor, or you lose 15-50% of what was in the chest. Maybe i'm playing the game wrong but dear lord, for being in early access since 2016, this game should not be this broken. It plays like an alpha build, the combat is braindead, hitboxes are shaky at best, automation aspects are broken(I'm talking  about the water cannon which specifically says it will make watering easier, well It only shoots in one static spot and you can't aim it so what use is that? to water one spot of farm?). There's a lot of good ideas here but I just cant get behind something that has been out for 6 years and doesn't seem to have made any progress.

I will say for a sandbox creative game it does provide a decent experience. The building is okay and it's fun to mess around building crazy things and just screwing around. However, this doesn't make up for the fact the survival mode is completely unbalanced and just not fun (not to mention that is their main focus in marketing... see Scrap Mechanic: Survival). I wouldn't even take the survival mode for free. I wish I could get a refund but I chose to give it a chance and play at least 15 hrs to see if it gets better. It does not.

I would rate the game 9/10. It would be even better if it had more frequent updates to keep the playerbase engaged, but other than that, the game is absolutely amazing and incredibly fun! My friend and I were so hooked on it that we played all night, went to school in the morning, and then came back home to continue playing.

The game really allows your imagination to run wild, which can be both a good and a bad thing. Sometimes, I think that the National Security might be monitoring us because of the way we talk and the advanced technology we develop in the game, capable of commiting crimes so unimaginable and goofy that the history books will credit us for the most damage to the robots in the game and make humankind think "damn i´m glad they were on our side". 

I'm really looking forward to Chapter 2. Even though Lego Powerminers might not make a comeback, we can still have fun roleplaying and reconstructing those sets while digging tunnels in Scrap Mechanic. can´t wait to systematically eradicate those underground robots for the fun of it!

I've been playing this game since day one of it's launch on steam, back then we didn't have survival mode, blueprints, a paint tool, not even a welder! This game has gone through so much change since January of 2016 that it's truly inspiring that such a small team of developers have put *SO* much care and detail into their work.

There have been times where i don't play the game for a while, but i *always* come back to it whenever i'm in the mood to just build whatever comes to mind in creative mode. The survival mode feels well thought out and while i do wish it was a bit more instructional on how to play for new players, i'm sure that will be expended in future updates.

The core gameplay mechanic (haha, pun) of building machines to accomplish your goals is simply incredible, something that I've wanted in a game for *years* before this came out, and i've been hooked ever since.

I will admit, there's a bit of jank to this game, it is still in development after all, but I've not come across anything in my over 650 hours of playing that was completely game breaking, unless it was something i did myself, usually involving mods so dabble in that at your own discretion if you like.

Overall, i'd place this game easily in the top 5 of all the games I've played in the last 25 years, if you haven't at least given it a try for yourself, do so now!

And yes it will be complex at first for newcomers, but it will get better in time. For me I liked this game so much that I bought it again so that I could transfer it from my old account to my new account... Which may have lost all 200+ hours I had... But at least it saved the amount of time I spent on worlds. Except it lost all my clothing items... And I can't seem to access any newly claimed ones... But who needs nice looking clothes when your building (almost) all of the vehicles from Halo! However I have noticed when trying to build a M808C Scorpion 1-1 scale, that the game did lag quite a lot... Even though I have way above recommended specs...

But hey, at least it doesn't crash, so thats good. Not to mention the survival mode is a lot of fun... It's just... Well... Warehouses. I can't seem to ever get enough spuds... But hey everything else is fun, especially those big red guys, oh they can do some damage. Until I pull up in my 300 ton wip, outfitted with drills, teir 3 concrete battering rams, and saw blades. While pulling a trailer that's twice the weight, carrying a fully automatic craft system. And if that ain't enough, I got 2 mountable spud guns... That I can't ever get enough spuds to use...

But yeah, fun game all in all, just watch what you build, and how you build it. The game might not like it.

It isn't fun if you plan to play solo survival... If you do have friends to play this game, then it might be worth your while. Or if you stick with creative mode. 

The robots (waves) are just too annoying, and all the tips people recommend on the forums are just useless to new beginners. There is no map, there are no basic guides (you need to look it all up on google), there is no storymode, just a sandbox with annoying robots. 

it has been EA since 2016 and it still is as rusty as I first started playing this game, seems nothing has changed over the past 7 years, which is kinda sad. I don't even know if they are actually updating this game. 

I can be "fun" for a while if you have friends playing together, but other than that, it rapidly gets old and boring. Unless you're one of those technical engineers who love to play with the car/motor mechanics... Casual players will not... 

So I can't recommend this game unfortunately... Especially because of the lack of actual improvements. Lack of Story, lack of basic information, and the attitude of "you'll need to google to find information" kind of game.

Within the first hour I made a 9M337 Sosna-R  Russian radar and laser-guided based supersonic two-stage missile system.  It is used in short range air defense missile system designed to protect military units from air attacks in all types of combat situations, including during march.

In 2017, official tests of the newest air defense missile system Bagulnik (domestic variant which is currently named Strela-10ML) were successfully completed. In May 2019, the Russian Defence Ministry decided to introduce the system into service. The Sosna-R missile system, developed by KB Tochmash, is a successor to the 9K35 Strela-10 and serves as a cost-effective alternative to the Tor missile system and Pantsir-S1. It operates in passive mode using various imaging systems such as thermal and TV cameras, along with a laser rangefinder, to detect and engage targets. The system can effectively function under the control of different battery command posts, with the FPU "Assembly-M1-2" (9S80M1-2) being the most preferred option due to its resistance to jamming. The Sosna-R system utilizes a tracked SAM launcher mounted on the MT-LB vehicle, capable of carrying 12 missiles with a range of 10 km and an altitude capability of 5 km. The reloading of all 12 missiles can be accomplished within 12 minutes.

The serial production version of the Sosna-R is based on the BMP-3 IFV and provides the ability to engage targets while on the move. The crew consists of a driver and a gunner. The system is armed with 12 9M340 missiles stored in transport-launch containers arranged in two banks of six. These 38 kg, two-stage missiles employ beam-riding guidance and are capable of engaging aircraft, helicopters, cruise missiles, aerial bombs, small-sized air attack weapons, high-precision weapon elements, and light armored vehicles. The missiles have the ability to change direction during flight and are equipped with a combined impact/proximity laser fuze. The payload includes two warheads weighing a total of 7 kg. The fragmented-rod warhead is designed for proximity detonation near the target, while the armor-piercing/fragmentation (AP-Frag) warhead is triggered upon impact. The system exhibits high resistance to jamming and can also be equipped with an additional small-size acquisition radar.

In addition to the Sosna-R missile system, the Palma anti-aircraft artillery system incorporates eight Sosna-R precision surface-to-air missiles with laser beam guidance, along with two AO-18KDE rapid-fire guns. The Palma system serves as a defensive component, intended for the protection of ships, naval bases, coastal infrastructure, aerodromes, and other vital facilities.

Don't buy it. Completely dishonest devs who don't respect Early Access, lie about working on the game, don't communicate openly, and simply let their game die without any meaningful update for years.

It boggles the mind that this was such a popular, loved game, and it would have been so easy to maintain a good pace of small but meaningful updates to the survival gameplay. But possibly they just got bored with working on it, or moved on to newer projects that are more profitable for them.

It's a smaller studio but apparently they work like the worst kind of capitalist corporations. Hell, even corporations understand how important is not to abandon things and ruin their image, especially if said things are generally successful.

With respect to the game's state: You can fool around for a while, build some really interesting and creative machines and bases, but soon it will be transparent that the entire game is completely unfinished, with no gameplay loop, no longer term goals, and no depth in the game mechanics.

Pros.   Great game, it does have quite a few bugs though. This game is heavy on your PC and does have a higher cost, but I think it's well worth it if you get it while on sale. This is one of my most played games and the replay ability is pretty good. Make sure to check out the mods too. 
Cons.   My biggest con is the time there is between updates, I do understand it is a complex game using their homemade physics engine as well as they have a small team, but it's killing the game, after three play through's of this game spanned over the few years I've owned it I've finally gotten to the point I can't do another play through without new content. The team has been promising and teasing content over the years but most of it has yet to come.

Update:
I am adding my voice along with others. I hope the devs pay attention, but they don't seem to look at steam or reply in steam at all.

They announce an update, then nothing..
They announce a new and different update, then nothing..
They announce another new and different update, then nothing..
Repeat.

Either the updates are a lie, or they really need to learn the term iterative development. Stop making new features and finish the ones you have already announced. 

Devs, the a majority of the community has lost faith in you.

I will update ... probably never.

The physics in this game are atrociously bad. Whenever i try and build anything more advanced then a car (2 bearings) the games physics fucking shit themself. even placing a flat plate of blocks on a flat ground makes them have palputation. Objects at high speed just dont interact at all, having more then 8 bearings on a creation lags. Having 2 creations next to each other lags horribly, all bearings spawn at 0 degrees position so good luck building some sort of part with rotated arms beacuse they will spawn in themself. Honestly the bearings are the most atrocious piece of gabage in this game. Sometimes when a vehicle hits something at high speed the bearing decide to not work and the parts that were connected just fly out everywhere phase through blocks and get stuck sometimes semi phasing inside the vehicle and make it take off beacuse they want to get back to their original position. Vehicles just jumping when up for no reason when driving on a flat road  (which you can actually see in the trailer), etc.

If someone says -well just lower the physics level, then a bunch of other shit brakes, like suspension just giving up entirely and not working. For a game made around vehicles with working parts you would think that physics would be top notch in orther for the creations to actually work but no. Its made really just to support baby shit like a car or a boat

*If anyone wonders im am a creative player and bought the game before survival was out, and play exclusively creative.
*If anyone wonders what ,,advanced'' vehicles am i building i mostly like building tanks, which often involve having multiple bearing moving  one object in the tank (for example a turret where you need at least 4 bearings for the wheels 2 bearings (without mods) for the turret, and 1 bearing for the gun to move up and down) and the shitty physics cant even handle something as basic as a turret moving without it getting stuck for no apparent reason when the vehicle is on a slope or even when its on flat ground

TL;DR Game has great potential but snail-pace development and limited Physics engine capabilities leaves a bitter taste.

This game has been in Early Access for ages and i followed it since then, at that point there was nothing but Sandbox stuff like building bases and vehicles to test out the games capability. (Will get on that quickly.)
Ever since then however its main selling point has been its worst outlier being a uncapable physics engine.
The Game barely uses resources from hardware and seems rather limited by its own software.

Then Survival came out which had a mixed start but eventually came on its own.
However the game has still been plagued by a major issue that has not been fixed, and barely remedied which of course is not enough for its issue;
Bad physics engine performance.

The frames crash down simply from having two cars next to each other, or a 4+ wheeler simply because, the suspension part is for some reason so demanding.
It's natural that players tend to build oversized vehicles or constructions in sandbox games and devs always need to have a engine bracing for it but this game engine doesn't even come close, 2 cars are enough for things to start to have an effect.

Several times me and my friends would have to drop the middle or lategame just because the game engine was stressed out just because of two 6 wheelers (One Harvester, the other a Transport) which aren't even doing anything besides being parked.

But of course the second we start driving it's all a slideshow.
We eventually dropped down to bogey suspension to have as little suspension parts as possible but the performance is still far too unsatisfactory.
We were not even close to finishing building the base.
We both are equipped with RTX machines neccessary for VR and the game barely uses the resources neccessary, as the game seemingly is limited by its own software.

Considering the snail-pace development, and that this issue has been lasting for 7 years with still consistent reports on Forums, this just not acceptable.

Great game, but the reason I bought it was for the survival mode. However, there are a few issues. Firstly, you can't drink water, yet you need to drink constantly. Secondly, you can't eat corn, only cows can, yet you have to eat every five minutes. Yes, you can farm, but as soon as you try to farm more than five blocks, bots swarm you, forcing you to constantly babysit the base instead of exploring. The game itself is excellent for building, but in terms of the survival mode, I wanted to enjoy it without constantly fighting hunger and thirst every five minutes, even though my house is built on water and there's an abundance of corn nearby. Why can't you eat the corn or drink regular water? Adding more options for eating and drinking would make me love to come back to the game.

I apologize for the lengthy review but I got some shit to get off my chest and to stand up for the mod community in this game.
- This game came out well over 6 years ago, they've made piss poor progress in updating, communicating actual timeframes and expanding the games internal systems. Best you get are the extremely irregular Dev blogs, that are more a- The Devs actively lobby against the modding community, sending Cease and Desists to mod creators and making their game harder and harder to modify. The fact they have such a HUGE community that wishes to play with mods, supporting with this should of been a no brainer for the Devs and Axolot...
- As for the games age well.... call me old but I'm getting nostalgic reminders of OG Rust Beta and its Legacy Age drama.... 
Its about time that Axolot starts adding smaller updates to the game and actually progressing the game. Make it fun to play again at the very least because holy cow that's what mods are for...

All I got to say to finish off this is... Axolot, start giving a shit about your community and make the game modifiable to a user friendly level. We payed you 20$ in good faith you'd actually make it out of Early access in the first 5 years... Its been well over  2 years since you put out a worthy update (Challenge mode doesn't count because its stupid and no one plays it), you've been teasing "major" updates for literal years... like y'all are compensating for something at this point.

Please stop hating the community of modders, and allow free integration of mods into your Survival mode. Something that we all have been asking for since we got as far as entertainment will allow.

Similar to Minecraft in gameplay, but has realistic* physics, making it very fun to make all sorts of vehicles. There's also logic gates, which, combined with the physics and wiring system, make almost any build far easier to make in Scrap Mechanic than in Minecraft.

*The physics are often a little glitchy. Watch out for the suspension glitch (tho it can be very useful too) and be ready for unstable physics when large forces and/or small distances are involved.

Scrap mechanic is one of the best games I have ever played. The building system, while simple is very effective at creating very detailed shapes. The logic system is even better, outdoing minecraft redstone by a mile. As of writing this, I have had the game for more than 4 years, with 600+ hours of playtime.

     creative mode: 
  creative mode is the first mode played by many players, for a good reason. creative mode is a good introduction to the game, the physics (which i will get into later) are consistent and can be reduced. the only problem with creative is the lack of... anything; yes, you can spawn bots and play against them, but if you don't have a friend to play with, creative gets boring and lame (known from experience.) additionally, if you have something that spins too fast and you step on it, it could yeet you out of the map, past the point of detection where the game keeps you in the map.

     survival: 
  survival fixes many of the problems with creative mode, and more; it gives you a sense of purpose, while being better with friend, it doesn't need them to keep from getting horribly boring. As much as i would like to explain the advantages to survival, most of them contain spoilers (therefore, i will not list them) the problems with survival are vast and many, the most clear one is the development era. the development era of survival was pre-survival it was full of many devblogs and teasers. it would have a release date but then get pushed back (due to covid) i am not blaming the devs for this, they had very few developers with such a small studio however, they greatly over hyped the survival release. first, they announced survival mode too soon, this would mean that people would get exited for it, but since survival wasn't even 1/8 done, many people's hope and patience died, causing the mode to get over hyped. additionally, there were too many devblogs with feature that never got implemented, these features may get added in future updates, but since they were announced and never added, the mode felt barren compared to what was announced. ignoring the over hyping of survival, the main problem is the grind; it isn't horrible, but it feels disappointing when you finally get something good (this will probably get fixed in chapter 2, where they are adding blueprints that you need to find)

     challenge mode: 
  this mode is my least favorite mode: it doesn't really do anything, and the skill curve feels off compared to the rest of the game (survival is medium hard at first, then it levels off. challenge is more exponential)

     mods: 
  mods are a great way to take the game and make it crazy, for many people, they only play with mods, for other people, the don't like mods. i cannot give a realistic review for mods since there are too many and they are heavily opinion based. 

     custom games: 
  to some people, survival is boring and bland, but they want mods to add to it. however, survival cant be modified without changing game files. so, how do you mod survival? make a custom game. custom games are great since they aren't mods, but infact, a baseline. a great example of a custom game is scrap factory (made by Dr. pixel plays) this custom game turns 'peaceful building game' into 'roblox tycoon but better' and that is just one of the examples of the stuff you can do with custom games.

     In conclusion, scrap mechanic is a great sandbox game for everyone and is worth the money, before you write a bad review, take a minute to check if the mode that you are playing is what you like, if not, then try another one.

Given that the survival mode hasn't received an update of any significance in over two years, and that the next update has no ETA the devs will commit to but will be the update that brings the game out of early access, you will see one of three things occur:

A) the update drops in 2023 with three years worth of content updates, bug fixes, and optimizations, giving us an entirely new game and bringing the survival mode and multiplayer experience to where they should be.

B) the update drops in 2023 and amounts to what is ultimately a minor story update and some new parts but does nothing to address: the lack of meaningful progression, the incredible grind for components, and the overall instability currently plaguing multiplayer. The game joins the ever-growing ranks of the physics builders with no actual gameplay a la Space Engineers or Stormworks. 

C) we get one or two more Devblogs but no update. Add one to every number or year listed above and continue waiting.

Bought into the early access over a year ago, played the survival and eventually got bored and stopped, waited for new content. Saw the update posts and thought I'd jump back in, experience some of the new content since it looked really cool.

Edit:

TL:DR The melee combat makes Skyrim look like Dark Souls, the terrain physics are a slippery nightmare, the farming makes me yearn for taxes and the one thing I wanted to do in the game, I never had time for.

As for the game itself, I got this for the survival. It is a slog. The concept of advancing and building up your vehicles sounds fun. The execution is not.

Gathering resources is a bit of a chore, but not too bad. The problem is what you get out of it, which is very little. And what you do get, you may have to refine and lose about 50% in the refining process.

The farming is an absolute chore. Easily the worst part of the game and it is tied to progression. In order to get a ranged weapon, you have to farm. Also to eat, but you can get around that, kind of. You HAVE to get a ranged weapon because the hammer is a goddamn slap fight with the fork bots.

Watering your farm is EXTREMELY tedious. Each soil plot needs to be watered each time you plant. This requires one bucket of water, that, in order to fill, you have to walk up to water and click for each bucket. In order to use buckets for watering, you'll need a lot of them, and they cost you precious resources and time. Watering can? What kind of space-age tech is that?  Alternatively it takes one shot of water from the watering cannon to water one plot. The watering cannon is not something you can hold, oh no, nothing fun like that, and it's not a stream, it's one little shot of water. You have to design a structure to irrigate your crops. Look it up on youtube, save yourself the nightmare. It sucks.

Then you need defenses, but defenses are frustrating too. Want a sawblade to defend your farm? Joke's on you, the damn bots shy away from it, making them perpetually stare at you, out of range of your defenses. They do this to your vehicles too, which makes the bots so annoying and not satisfying to deal with. Having them standing still would be great with a potato gun, but if you don't, now you have to step outside your defenses and melee them, which is a nightmare all it's own. Oh and if there are multiple bots, you're probably going to die, and god I hope you remembered to put your spawn point nearby.

All of this crap takes away from the reason I got this game: To make cool vehicles to overcome terrain and other challenges in the survival world. But most of my time spent was on keeping fed, designing a farm and watering, gathering resources with minuscule returns, fighting with physics scrounging for component kits to make literally anything you build actually worth a damn... it's not fun. It's busywork stopping you from exploring an interesting world ( which is not present, as far as I know,) or overcoming challenges using your vehicles and tools.

What ended my last run was welding. My trailer, which had all of my chests full of resources, kept sliding and rolling around on the uneven terrain of my temporary base. I tried blocking it's wheels and it would still somehow slide along the ground. I took the wheels off and it would still slide. I eventually got fed up and welded it to the terrain, and that worked. However that was along the path the bots would spawn every night to attack the farm. So I tried to put it off to the side and weld it to the rock wall.  Unfortunately, it welded upside down, and the majority of my trailer became submerged into the terrain. I broke the piece attaching it to the wall, but nope. It is now a structure, with all of my chests completely inaccessible. Fuck you scrap mechanic and your buggy, wonky physics.

I did not care for this game so I will place here a recipe for huckleberry pancakes instead.

Huckleberry pancakes.

1 3/4 cups all purpose white flour
4 tablespoons sugar
1 tablespoon baking powder
1/4 teaspoon salt
1 1/2 cups of buttermilk
5 tablespoon butter, melted
2 large eggs
1/2 cup Huckleberries
In medium bowl combine flour, sugar, baking powder and salt, set aside. In small bowl combine buttermilk, butter and eggs. Add buttermilk mixture to the flour mixture, combine until mixed do not over mix (I prefer to use a whisk it does the best job). Fry at 400 degrees. Pour about 1/4 cup of batter on the griddle and sprinkle with the huckleberries.

Cook on first side about 3 minutes until bubbles appear along the edge of the pancake. Flip and cook for 2 minutes more and golden brown. Serve with a big pat of butter, and some pure maple syrup ( get the real stuff it is worth it).

TL;DR: I cannot recommend this game in it's current state. The advertised gameplay is barely present, it is unplayable without a guide, and it offers very little for the money you're spending. The devs abandoned this game for 3 years, and based on the recent dev blog, I do not have high hopes for improvement anytime soon.

I really enjoyed this game in the beginning, but I am updating my review to say that I have grown pretty disappointed in it since I purchased it 2.5 years ago. Since then, I've played many more small team Early Access titles, including others from this developer, and they have far exceeded the offerings we have been stuck with for some time now.

I think the source of my feelings stems from the fact that the developers decided that the story mode and gameplay should take a back seat to their sandbox vehicle builder. It became "how can we make funny car physics" the game, instead of that mechanic adding a unique twist to the story mode gameplay, as is advertised.

Even with the little story that does exist, it takes an excruciatingly long amount of time to make any progress with it. It felt like we were grinding for hours and not getting anywhere because managing hunger and thirst was such a burden. I tried replaying it with a variety of different people, and each time we hit a point where managing resources was all we were doing, and it got tiresome really quickly. 

Also, there is very little guidance provided - No tutorial, no storyline to follow, no hints. You HAVE to play this with the wiki open to figure out even the most basic game mechanics. Without it, the game is impossible to progress in.

The team has just come back from hiatus to update the game again, and what they're offering is... More enemy types? In my opinion, the storymode in this game needs a huge overhaul before they start adding in more shiny things for us to look at. Otherwise, the team may as well re-brand the game as a funny vehicle driving simulator.

Very nice little game. Good physics and a decent variety of things to build with. In its current state, however, it is not worth the purchase. Development seems to be pretty slow, and it's currently in the funk of Early Access where you can't tell if it is going to pan out yet. 

When it becomes more content complete, may very well be a solid game, but right now not worth it.

================================

UPDATE (Spring 2018): Almost two years since I wrote this review, this game has made almost no large-scale, meaningful progress.

I classified this experience as a fun little sandbox to mess around in, with some neat little features.

Today, it's no different. Just a cute little sandbox with some tools to mess around with. 

There really just isn't much of an excuse. Look at Rust, having a comparable dev team, and pushing out significant content patches on a weekly or biweekly schedule.

================================

UPDATE 2 (Summer 2018): After giving up pretty hard on the game's pace of development, I've noticed that the last few months have seen much much more meaningful progress towards survival mode and the gameplay that the game initially hoped to feature. The quality of updates has increased dramatically in every sense. I really hope that we can see survival mode in the next year or so.

================================

UPDATE 3 (Winter 2019): Well I guess my hopes were a bit much, we're four years into Early Access, and there's still no end in sight. Who knows, at one point it might get there. Here's hoping that the game is even functional and playable when they've finished filling it with content, given how inconsistent the game's performance seems to be.

================================

UPDATE 4 (Winter 2021): Jeez, it's been two years since I took a look at this game and it's still not even close to being a functional, complete work.

Every update blog says the same thing: Delay, Some Progress, Delay, Some Progress, Delay. 

Tons of new fluffy doohickeys to mess around with, but still looks like there's no... game...

See you all in another 2 years? Maybe then we'll be there?

=================================

UPDATE 5 (Summer 2023): I guess they're still working on the game? Could have fooled me!

I see there have been no released updates for two years, but their social media has been active and every few months they post an update about a huge "Chapter 2" update. 1) Stop ignoring people asking for more communication on update progress and release dates. 2) If you bit off more than you could chew with the huge "Chapter 2" update you're planning, you need to ship smaller updates. Your game still needs some really basic stuff.

- It needs a map, or at least a compass
- I spent 30 hours wondering why this game didn't have a block, or any kind of defense option, only to find out that the sledgehammer has a block but it's ONLY IN CREATIVE MODE AND NOT IMPLEMENTED IN SURVIVAL? COME ON
- I keep accidentally putting switches inside walls and 16x16 slabs inside floors that are gone forever, hanging inside the void just out of reach. Your building mode needs polish - and you're ignoring it to work on a new "mining" mode?
- An enemy that can swarm you in numbers, and kills you in two ranged hits, on "NORMAL" mode in a game with no armor and only one kind of health item that takes whole seconds to use is ridiculous
- My character is currently stuck inside the "outside" area of one of the vent ducts in a warehouse, after one of the red grenade robots started shooting grenades into a vent I was in, destroying the floor underneath me. This is the point where I'm putting down the game. This is something that REALLY BASIC PLAYTESTING would have told you needed some work. You folks need to get it together.

[b]2023 Review:[/b]
I miss when this game received updates. Since the release of survival mode in 2020, this game has seen no substantial additions aside from a yearly drip feed of content for challenge mode. As it stands, survival mode itself is nothing special, and content for creative mode has stagnated. If you've never played it before, Scrap Mechanic is still worth the $20 for creative mode alone, but if you're buying it for a survival experience, or returning after a few years hoping for something new, you will likely walk away underwhelmed.


[b]2017 Review:[/b]
If you have an imagination and love building things with moving parts, get this game! It isn't too hard to understand, the only skill required is a basic grasp of sequencing tasks (rotate bearing 90 degrees, then extend piston 7 blocks). Currently the game only has creative mode and a single map, but survival mode and procedurally generated worlds are planned. There are also currently no weapons in the game, but potato guns are going to be added in a future update.

TL;DR

Pros
-Lots of fun tools to work with
-Relatively frequent updates
-Easy to understand
-Good physics engine
-Your imagination is the limit (you can build anything you can think of)
-Steam workshop support
-You can put two toilet paper rolls together to make a paper towel roll

Cons
-Early Access, so survival mode, day/night cycle, weapons, and enemies are not yet added
-May lag depending on how complex your creations are
-No player customization (yet)
-Your imagination is the limit (you can't build it unless you're able to think of it)

Overall, creative people will enjoy how much this game has to offer, but people with limited creativity may find themselves getting bored after a few hours.

This game is a finely crafted masterpiece by Axolot games, it is a simple game where you make various machines from the humble automobile to the complicated self stabilizing rocket. This game is a game for all ages, so simple yet so complicated.

Overall, I would recommend scrap mechanic to everyone.

There are a couple of things that I think could improve the overall experience while we wait for the next update, hopefully coming soon.

1. While I have close to 500 hours on record at the time of posting a review, the game at this time feels a bit empty. I have completed all warehouses, and all I have left to do at this point is finalize my base while waiting for chapter 2. I would like to see more frequent updates with smaller amounts of content rather than the tsunami of content being promised by the developers for over 2 years now. For future content updates, it would be great if we seen new content every couple of months, even if on a smaller scale.

2. Multiplayer improvements would be a great area to be focused on if nothing is fixed in the upcoming update. At this time, multiplayer is practically unplayable with the amount of issues surrounding it, hopefully the developers will focus their time and resources to fix this so playing with friends is a much smoother experience. Because we all know, games like Scrap Mechanic is much more fun with friends.

Overall, this game is a great experience. It is a challenge to the mind to figure out all the different things you can create with the available parts, but it will be much better to get new content to play with, hopefully coming soon rather than later. I love this game and knowing the fanbase is dying out due to a lack of content and what feels like empty promises from the developers, I am hopeful Scrap Mechanic will become revitalized with a player base that can enjoy the game as much as I have.

Long time between updates?  Admittedly, yes.  BUT ...

The loop:
Grow food, defend against the bots who are upset by your farming, eat, drink, gather up their parts and local resources to expand production, repeat.

What's here is a complete game, and a far more complete experience than a good deal of "finished" games.  There's not just physics construction, but reasons to do so; problems to deal with and challenges to overcome.  And I'm talking about in survival, not just the challenge levels.

The game progresses smoothly, gives you the basics in a straightforward manner, and leaves you to your own devices.

Surviving is not difficult; growing enough food to keep the mechanic alive is easy to do even without angering the bots, which leaves plenty of time to figure out how to build something bigger, better, faster or ... more specialized.

Trees don't respawn ... instead, as you gather materials and locate landmarks, the cramped forests become rolling landscapes where you can see roaming little bots from greater distances, making it easier to line them up and run them over with a combine (for instance), snatching up their dismembered limbs for use in an even larger combine.

I've been enjoying it again lately, and can heartily recommend it as a very enjoyable game.  While it is still in early access, and it's updates are few and far between, this game is already easily worth the $20.  It's a unique take with impressive stability.  There's nothing just broken here, and that alone is a big deal in this market.

I love this game so much, and with such raw passion.
However.  The Dev team is out of touch.  It's been 3 years since survival released. I don't want to sound like a "whiny gamer" but its frustrating considering after 250 hours i set the game down to wait for the next survival update.  That was 2 years ago.  I imagine Covid played a part in this, as did the final push to get raft finished.  (but now theyre pushing that to consoles so....the dev support i thought scrap mechanic was going to get, probably won't happen.)

The grind in this game is unreal.  Without mods to adjust drop rates for things, the grind takes forever alone.  I think the reason the drop rates are so low is because even with a decent pc (3070 10700k, my pc is no slouch)  a small automated farm and a couple complex vehicles absolutely TANK fps.  Very heavily CPU bound, mainly because the physics all run off one core. 

The Devs seem to like to go AWOL for 6 months at a time?  To the point where the community considers this game abandonware.  I think they had some major direction problems in chapter 2 development, not knowing where to take the game, while being choked by their physx problems, only to then get tbagged by covid shot this game in the foot.  

I'm only not recommending this game until the new "massive" update comes out.  IF what the devs say is true, we should be getting an entire game rebalance, and over double the content and pretty much everything the community has asked for and more...We just want the devs to communicate more.  Tease us, even if its just a tweet every couple weeks.
