Hey Mum you can be proud of your son now, because I'm a graduated engineer thanks to the Scrap Mechanic Engineer Academy.
I used to fill up shelfs at Wal-Mart and Tesco, but Scrap Mechanic Survival gave me a new opportunity and i don't need to work in these lesser-class jobs anymore.
Be like me, buy your own diploma now for 19.99€ and fulfill your dreams.

Now to the serious part:

Scrap Mechanic is a sandbox-style game that allows you to build and design your own vehicles, machines, and contraptions in a sprawling open-world environment. Developed by Axolot Games, the game offers a unique and engaging gameplay experience that rewards creativity and experimentation.

In the game, you play as a mechanic who has crash-landed on a planet filled with scrap material and hostile robots. You must scavenge for resources, build and customize your own vehicles, and fend off the robotic enemies that inhabit the world.

One of the game's standout features is its building system. The game offers a wide variety of building blocks and parts that you can use to create almost anything you can imagine, from simple cars to complex machines that perform a variety of functions. The building system is intuitive and easy to use, with a wide range of tools and functions that allow you to create and customize your creations in real-time.

The game's graphics are also impressive, with a colorful and vibrant art style that makes the world feel alive and dynamic. The game's sound design is also top-notch, with a variety of sound effects and musical cues that add to the game's immersive atmosphere.

In addition to the main campaign, the game offers a variety of multiplayer modes that allow you to collaborate and compete with other players from around the world. This adds a level of community to the game, as you can share your creations with others and discover new and innovative designs from other players.

One potential downside to the game is that it can be somewhat challenging at times, especially when it comes to building more complex machines and vehicles. However, this also adds a level of depth and strategy to the game, as you must think critically and plan out your designs in order to succeed.

In conclusion, Scrap Mechanic is a fun and engaging sandbox-style game that rewards creativity and experimentation. With its intuitive building system, vibrant graphics, and immersive sound design, this game is a must-play for anyone who loves to tinker and create. Highly recommended!

This game is an absolute trainwreck.

Everything in this game is completely and utterly dysfunctional. Not a single thing I think I have done in this game has worked as it should, to the point where it is quite frankly, impossible to play. The physics engine in this game is so infuriatingly bad, that collision is not a feature, and rather a bug. Collisions between creations send your FPS so low it might as well be displayed as a fraction. Also, bearings and pistons are somehow not strong enough to hold themselves together and will sag so much that it'll become completely detached and start floating a metre away. The game also includes suspensions, but they will provide your creation with enough rotational momentum to send you spinning in constant circles with more than enough force to take off from the ground after simply colliding with pretty much anything. Not only is the physics bad in the first place, but it’s incredibly unoptimised and laggy, especially between creations, as mentioned earlier.  The developers however, for ONE TIME in their lives, listened to the community, and added a physics slider. The developers, however, made this feature completely and utterly useless, because using said slider will somehow make the bearings EVEN SAGGIER, to the point where they have complete 3 axis movement in all directions. The terrain has horrible collision, to the point where half the time there's no collision at all. If your character has enough velocity, they will simply fall right through and you'll get this annoying pop-up saying "Hey! You're playing the game wrong!" as if there's a right way to play this steaming pile of crap. Then, you'll be teleported up, and for some reason in survival, you'll be teleported so high you'll probably end up falling right through again.

Speaking of survival, it is so incomprehensibly broken and boring to the point where it's no longer a game anymore. I don't know how anyone could play survival without half of the main story items (if there even is a story), because half of them are missing and if you even can get them, they will probably fall through the map somehow. To give an example of how common this is, during every single one of my playthroughs, at least one thing has fallen through the floor, into the abyss never to be seen again while being kept entirely still as I explore the map. The story, however, is so half baked that it barely ties in together at all. It's lazy, disorganised, and completely contradictory. The map is also filled with warehouses, their only purpose being a little bit of loot, some cosmetic items, and most importantly, some special seeds. Different warehouses have different amounts of levels, each level getting harder. However, the warehouses with more levels have no more loot than the smaller ones meaning there is no real reason to battle your way through them. Survival mode is mostly spent grinding for component kits just so you can upgrade your creations, or fuel to power them, but there is one thing that really takes over the survival gameplay loop: farming. Farming is incredibly important in survival, as it will supply you with ammo for your ranged spud guns, food, and probably most importantly, it will allow you to package your produce. The reason why packaged fruits and vegetables is so useful is because you can use them to trade with the trader. The trader is the only way to acquire spud guns, which is pretty much its only use, as the rest of the items are extremely overpriced. The special seeds mentioned during the earlier segment on warehouses are used for trading, their use being for the spud shotgun, and spudling gun. However, these guns are not necessary at all and are quite expensive considering that planting these seeds will up the difficulty of your farming. The reason farming these more advanced fruits and vegetables is harder is because of the raid system. Each night, your farm will be raided by a collection of bots, found throughout the map, who will try to destroy the crops. The more advanced the seeds are, the more bots will come, and the stronger the bots will be. Not only this, but some crops take multiple days to grow, unless you use fertiliser. You will have to re-water each crop every time you farm, and you will have to fight off the bots over and over again each time you farm, just to get some basic resources or to slightly “upgrade” your weapon. In my opinion, the fact that you will have to spend most of your entire playthrough doing the same, gruelling tasks repeatedly just to slightly progress or create a basic contraption, simply isn’t worth the time, and unless you are more focused on achieving things like the alternative weapons, limits off a lot of the fun in this game.

The worst part is survival isn't even the main focus of the game. The main, original, mode is creative, and is also riddled with bugs. The map in creative is WAY smaller even after they increased the maximum map size. The main focus on the creative mode is on, well, being creative. However, it doesn't it do very well. Any innovative idea you have will be slammed head first into a metaphorical brick wall until you regret any intentions of executing it. In the end, you usually end up either having to scrap the idea entirely, do the same idea over and over again slight differently each time, or if you're dedicated, then painstakingly tweak and remaster the design until it works (if it works). Now, I'm going to talk about the multiplayer. Oh boy is the multiplayer absolutely UNPLAYABLY HORRENDOUS. I played this game a lot with my friend and he could not take one step without the game sending him into a jittery mess of random velocity and collisionless teleportation. Even past the most basic features, it somehow gets even worse. The optimisation in multiplayer is almost non-existent and chaos ensues should you spawn in an even slightly complex creation. You know what I said earlier about saggy bearings, well anything that involves physics with something it’s attached to will end up completely desynced half the time and will jitter and overextend only to correct itself moments later, disorientating the player. Also, a bit problem is the input lag. To be fair, it’s usually when playing with an unoptimised mod, but when there’s input lag moving around is almost impossible. Blocks place a second late, your character moves a second late, everything happens a second after it should. Usually, the result of this is clearing the whole world, losing progress on old creations, just for it to have a chance of working again.

The developers decided to add one final mode, called "Challenge Mode". However, challenge mode doesn't have many of the parts and features and has no real extra features of its own apart from the basic mechanics. It’s not really a main mode and doesn't contribute much at all to the game. In addition, Challenge Mode suffers from a lot of bugs that will probably not get fixed for ages if at all. There are many incidents of not just me, not just my friend, but even youtubers and just the general community, crashing for no real reason during challenge mode. Previously, it was also hard to get some things working due to the limitations only lifted almost 4 years after its release in the 0.6.0 update that added 10 new inbuilt levels, a cosmetic set for beating all 50 of them, and some copied, long-overdue features from survival.

Apparently, that wasn't enough though, as in the same 0.6.0 update the developers decided to add a new game mode. They titled it "Custom Game", and it's a way for modders to make their own game modes using the “Scrap Mechanic Mod Tool”, which was overhauled in the same update. This was a good feature from Axolot purely because it allowed dedicated and talented people to fix the mistakes they couldn't.

In conclusion, this game is absolutely amazing, and I would recommended it to anyone of all kinds. It's really fun especially with friends.

2023 edit: Still very rough. Would not recommend.

Multiplayer has server-wide lag spikes which as far as I can tell are unavoidable. Animation bugs look silly, certain items cannot be picked up if placed in certain places, among a myriad of other small issues.

Survival is not ready for public consumption. Certain resources seem to simple have a chance to never spawn, and it lacks an overarching ultimate goal. What more is that the balance hits this uncanny valley. This game's greatest strength is being able to create interesting contraptions. But just getting to that point requires a ton a resource grinding and luck. My GF & I literally spent 4 hours between us just looking for cotton, and could never find a single one. Making basic things should be cheap and easy, and those basic things can be used to harvest enough resources to feed into advanced things.

Otherwise, creative mode is pretty good if you can motivate yourself to create. 

Maybe it'll be worth it in 1-2 years, but please avoid for now.

According to all known laws
of aviation,


there is no way a bee
should be able to fly.


Its wings are too small to get
its fat little body off the ground.

The bee, of course, flies anyway


because bees don't care
what humans think is impossible.


Yellow, black. Yellow, black.
Yellow, black. Yellow, black.


Ooh, black and yellow!
Let's shake it up a little.


Barry! Breakfast is ready!


Coming!


Hang on a second.


Hello?

- Barry?
- Adam?


- Can you believe this is happening?
- I can't. I'll pick you up.


Looking sharp.


Use the stairs. Your father
paid good money for those.


Sorry. I'm excited.


Here's the graduate.
We're very proud of you, son.


A perfect report card, all B's.

Very proud.


Ma! I got a thing going here.


- You got lint on your fuzz.
- Ow! That's me!


- Wave to us! We'll be in row 118,000.
- Bye!


Barry, I told you,
stop flying in the house!


- Hey, Adam.
- Hey, Barry.


- Is that fuzz gel?
- A little. Special day, graduation.


Never thought I'd make it.


Three days grade school,
three days high school.


Those were awkward.


Three days college. I'm glad I took
a day and hitchhiked around the hive.


You did come back different.


- Hi, Barry.
- Artie, growing a mustache? Looks good.


- Hear about Frankie?
- Yeah.


- You going to the funeral?
- No, I'm not going.


Everybody knows,
sting someone, you die.


Don't waste it on a squirrel.
Such a hothead.


I guess he could have
just gotten out of the way.


I love this incorporating
an amusement park into our day.


That's why we don't need vacations.


Boy, quite a bit of pomp...
under the circumstances.


- Well, Adam, today we are men.
- We are!


- Bee-men.
- Amen!


Hallelujah!


Students, faculty, distinguished bees,


please welcome Dean Buzzwell.


Welcome, New Hive Oity
graduating class of...


...9:15.


That concludes our ceremonies.


And begins your career
at Honex Industries!


Will we pick our job today?


I heard it's just orientation.


Heads up! Here we go.


Keep your hands and antennas
inside the tram at all times.


- Wonder what it'll be like?
- A little scary.


Welcome to Honex,
a division of Honesco


and a part of the Hexagon Group.


This is it!


Wow.


Wow.


We know that you, as a bee,
have worked your whole life


to get to the point where you
can work for your whole life.


Honey begins when our valiant Pollen
Jocks bring the nectar to the hive.


Our top-secret formula


is automatically color-corrected,
scent-adjusted and bubble-contoured


into this soothing sweet syrup


with its distinctive
golden glow you know as...


Honey!


- That girl was hot.
- She's my cousin!


- She is?
- Yes, we're all cousins.


- Right. You're right.
- At Honex, we constantly strive


to improve every aspect
of bee existence.


These bees are stress-testing
a new helmet technology.


- What do you think he makes?
- Not enough.


Here we have our latest advancement,
the Krelman.


- What does that do?
- Catches that little strand of honey


that hangs after you pour it.
Saves us millions.


Can anyone work on the Krelman?


Of course. Most bee jobs are
small ones. But bees know


that every small job,
if it's done well, means a lot.


But choose carefully


because you'll stay in the job
you pick for the rest of your life.


The same job the rest of your life?
I didn't know that.


What's the difference?


You'll be happy to know that bees,
as a species, haven't had one day off


in 27 million years.


So you'll just work us to death?


We'll sure try.


Wow! That blew my mind!


"What's the difference?"
How can you say that?


One job forever?
That's an insane choice to have to make.


I'm relieved. Now we only have
to make one decision in life.


But, Adam, how could they
never have told us that?


Why would you question anything?
We're bees.


We're the most perfectly
functioning society on Earth.


You ever think maybe things
work a little too well here?


Like what? Give me one example.


I don't know. But you know
what I'm talking about.


Please clear the gate.
Royal Nectar Force on approach.


Wait a second. Oheck it out.


- Hey, those are Pollen Jocks!
- Wow.


I've never seen them this close.


They know what it's like
outside the hive.


Yeah, but some don't come back.


- Hey, Jocks!
- Hi, Jocks!


You guys did great!


You're monsters!
You're sky freaks! I love it! I love it!


- I wonder where they were.
- I don't know.


Their day's not planned.


Outside the hive, flying who knows
where, doing who knows what.


You can'tjust decide to be a Pollen
Jock. You have to be bred for that.


Right.


Look. That's more pollen
than you and I will see in a lifetime.


It's just a status symbol.
Bees make too much of it.


Perhaps. Unless you're wearing it
and the ladies see you wearing it.


Those ladies?
Aren't they our cousins too?


Distant. Distant.


Look at these two.


- Oouple of Hive Harrys.
- Let's have fun with them.


It must be dangerous
being a Pollen Jock.


Yeah. Once a bear pinned me
against a mushroom!


He had a paw on my throat,
and with the other, he was slapping me!


- Oh, my!
- I never thought I'd knock him out.


What were you doing during this?


Trying to alert the authorities.


I can autograph that.


A little gusty out there today,
wasn't it, comrades?


Yeah. Gusty.


We're hitting a sunflower patch
six miles from here tomorrow.


- Six miles, huh?
- Barry!


A puddle jump for us,
but maybe you're not up for it.


- Maybe I am.
- You are not!


We're going 0900 at J-Gate.


What do you think, buzzy-boy?
Are you bee enough?


I might be. It all depends
on what 0900 means.


Hey, Honex!


Dad, you surprised me.


You decide what you're interested in?


- Well, there's a lot of choices.
- But you only get one.


Do you ever get bored
doing the same job every day?


Son, let me tell you about stirring.


You grab that stick, and you just
move it around, and you stir it around.


You get yourself into a rhythm.
It's a beautiful thing.


You know, Dad,
the more I think about it,


maybe the honey field
just isn't right for me.


You were thinking of what,
making balloon animals?


That's a bad job
for a guy with a stinger.


Janet, your son's not sure
he wants to go into honey!


- Barry, you are so funny sometimes.
- I'm not trying to be funny.


You're not funny! You're going
into honey. Our son, the stirrer!


- You're gonna be a stirrer?
- No one's listening to me!


Wait till you see the sticks I have.


I could say anything right now.
I'm gonna get an ant tattoo!


Let's open some honey and celebrate!


Maybe I'll pierce my thorax.
Shave my antennae.


Shack up with a grasshopper. Get
a gold tooth and call everybody "dawg"!


I'm so proud.


- We're starting work today!
- Today's the day.


Oome on! All the good jobs
will be gone.


Yeah, right.


Pollen counting, stunt bee, pouring,
stirrer, front desk, hair removal...


- Is it still available?
- Hang on. Two left!


One of them's yours! Oongratulations!
Step to the side.


- What'd you get?
- Picking crud out. Stellar!


Wow!


Oouple of newbies?


Yes, sir! Our first day! We are ready!


Make your choice.


- You want to go first?
- No, you go.


Oh, my. What's available?


Restroom attendant's open,
not for the reason you think.


- Any chance of getting the Krelman?
- Sure, you're on.


I'm sorry, the Krelman just closed out.


Wax monkey's always open.


The Krelman opened up again.


What happened?


A bee died. Makes an opening. See?
He's dead. Another dead one.


Deady. Deadified. Two more dead.


Dead from the neck up.
Dead from the neck down. That's life!


Oh, this is so hard!


Heating, cooling,
stunt bee, pourer, stirrer,


humming, inspector number seven,
lint coordinator, stripe supervisor,


mite wrangler. Barry, what
do you think I should... Barry?


Barry!


All right, we've got the sunflower patch
in quadrant nine...


What happened to you?
Where are you?


- I'm going out.
- Out? Out where?


- Out there.
- Oh, no!

As a player who has spent 144 hours in Scrap Mechanic and eagerly awaits the next update, I can say that this game is both engaging and creatively stimulating. It offers a plethora of possibilities for building and experimenting, as well as a very user-friendly building system.[hr][/hr]If you enjoy building and tinkering, Scrap Mechanic is the game for you. You can create any kind of machinery or transportation device that you can imagine, and the game has a vast array of parts and materials to enable building of complex and detailed machines.[hr][/hr]Moreover, the game offers a variety of tasks to accomplish, which expands the possibilities for creative experimentation. The best part of Scrap Mechanic is the ability to share your creations with other players, which adds even more interactivity to the game.[hr][/hr]I am eagerly anticipating the next update, which promises to add even more materials and building opportunities. I would recommend Scrap Mechanic to anyone who enjoys creating and tinkering - this game will certainly satisfy your creative impulses.

"I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 16. My son recently started Dinkum and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories."

scrap mechanic for life.

Pretty much Minecraft but with smaller blocks and (as of my review) a complete lack of terraforming. Legos, if you will... 

As with any creation based game, you are almost entirely limited to your imagination; whether that is limited to recreating objects from other games / movies / franchises or creating your own unique designs. As with most creation based games, you are locked to a 90 degree build grid which is the only other limitation.

As for the game: the survival mode was exciting at first but quickly became dull without any real goal. The story is not existant (chapter 2 will introduce quests and the story line).

For the game mechanics: logic can get pretty hectic, but other than that the game is relatively simple, with the hardest thing being creating neutrally buoyant aircraft.

Updates are few and far between, sometimes taking so long it almost feels like the dev(s) gave up on the game. 

Overall I would give it an 6.5 out of 10, just because it is a rather average creation game, but could easily turn into an 8-10 depending on the quality of the Chapter 2 release and all future updates down the road.

I really. REALLY. Love this game. So much. Just the endless creativity, making massive cars, hypersonic flyers, mechs, in creative. And the 'creativity in a box' survival, making your builds more practical and making everything have a purpose, and the excellent art style and story telling (my favorite mode). All of that makes it such a good game. It does have its flaws, like multiplayer being buggy, physics can be slightly lacking, and it having a pretty steep learning curve. But once your past that, this game is a blast. It is sad to see Axolot's recent radio silence on updates, but im hoping, and staying optimistic, that they will release and devblog or and update soon. The physics engine is amazing, leagues ahead of Kerbal Space Program or pretty much any vehicle builder to date. You can build transforming machines that don't explode when the moving parts collide. Creative mode is amazing. It might even be good enough to recommend this game for Creative Mode alone. The only thing that bugs me is the wheel physics could be better, racecar physics one area where the game Trailmakers is far, far better.

Challenge Mode is excellent, it give you limited parts and asks you to build a vehicle to solve a puzzle. This is honestly where Scrap Mechanic shines, in my opinion. It focuses on the best parts of the game, being the impressive physics engine and programmable parts.

Survival mode is a mixed bag, I recommend bringing a friend for it, since there is some grind at first gathering materials. There are fun puzzles you can solve by building machines to help accomplish tasks such as gathering wood and stone, rescuing trapped farmers and packaging and transporting produce to the trader. These legitimately challenge you to actually build machines with some complexity, which like I said is where the game shines... The dungeons, on the other hand, are generally designed to go into on foot with a melee weapon or spudgun, turning the game into a discount FPS.  I personally feel this takes away from the game's focus on building vehicles. Survival mode is still fun though, and rather addictive.

[hr][/hr]
[b]TL/DR[/b]
    • Scrap Mechanic is a sandbox game for creating machines, contraptions, and vehicles.
    • The game's mechanics and physics are outstanding and feel realistic.
    • Graphics are impressive with vibrant colors and attention to detail.
    • Single-player mode has various missions and challenges.
    • Multiplayer mode allows players to collaborate and build together.
    • Steep learning curve for new players, but helpful tutorials and community.
    • Excellent for creative building, problem-solving, and social gameplay.
    • Overall, Scrap Mechanic is definitely worth checking out.
[hr][/hr]
Scrap Mechanic is a fantastic sandbox game that allows players to create their own machines, contraptions, and vehicles using various materials and components. 

[b]Mechanics/Physics[/b]
First and foremost, the game's mechanics and physics are simply outstanding. The movements of the objects, as well as their weight and momentum, all feel incredibly realistic. This means that players will have to carefully consider the designs and materials they use when creating their machines, and it adds an element of challenge and creativity to the gameplay.

[b]Graphics/Sound Design[/b]
The graphics are also impressive, with vibrant colors and excellent attention to detail. The world feels alive, with different environments, creatures, and objects that add to the game's immersive experience. The sound design is also well-done, with appropriate sound effects and a catchy soundtrack that adds to the overall fun factor.

[b]Multiplayer[/b]
The game's single-player mode is enjoyable, with various missions and challenges to complete. However, where Scrap Mechanic really shines is in its multiplayer mode. The game allows players to collaborate and build together, which can lead to some truly impressive creations. Players can also join public servers or create their own, providing plenty of opportunities for social gameplay.

[b]Difficulty[/b]
One of the only downsides to Scrap Mechanic is that it can be a bit overwhelming for new players. The game has a steep learning curve, with a large number of materials, components, and mechanics to master. However, the game's tutorials and helpful community can make this process much smoother.
[hr][/hr]
Overall, Scrap Mechanic is an excellent sandbox game that provides endless hours of entertainment for players who enjoy creative building, problem-solving, and social gameplay. With its impressive graphics, realistic physics, and fun multiplayer mode, it's definitely worth checking out!

An excellent vehicle building game that is gatekeeped by an unusually un-fun early game. Getting off the ground is difficult, and the game doesn't provide you with any direction on your priority list. You can waste LOADS of time if you don't know what you're doing. So, here's How To Get To The Fun Part.
Firstly, start in the Puzzle/Challenge mode. This will help you learn the basics of How To Build Vehicles, with limited parts lists and clear objectives. You don't have to 100% it, but its plenty fun and will guide you through vehicle design pretty damn well. Then, once you have some friends on, load up your survival file.

After getting to the mechanic shop, make a Craft bot and a resource refiner, then AS SOON AS YOU ARE ABLE, make a Gas Engine, a Drill, and a Resource Container. This will let you start mining the big stone blocks for metal, which is about 10X faster than trying to kill robots for it.

Follow that with better tires and driver's seat, buzz saws to harvest trees, a second resource container so you can hot swap, for the muncher to munch while you're harvesting, and from there the game really opens up!

This game has potential, but they are reeeeeal slow on releasing content and information. 

What you get right now is a pretty fun experience creating a slew of different vehicles and devices. The system for making moving part is fairly straight forward allowing you to make anything from a simple door to as complex as a house that folds up into a car.

I played creative mode only a little bit. Honestly, this is probable where the game shines most at this point.

Survival mode is pretty fun, but without any major endgame goals. Collecting resources and slowly building your first rudimentary contraptions is great! Later on however,  'Dungeons' or whatever they are called do not allow you to build. It sort of defeats the purpose of being a 'Scrap Mechanic'. If your creative, you can fit a small vehicle through the entrance, but it doesn't feel like this was intended. More of a happy accident.

The combat is currently lacking. It ranges from easily kite-able melee bots to ranged enemies that blow through your health in a few hits as soon as they are agroed. It can be fun to create contraptions to kill bots, but it's sometimes hit or miss when they take damage.

Only bought this to play with a friend. 
In the base game we quickly ran out of things to do, so we installed some mods. 
Added a lot more gametime and goals for us. But the Multiplayer.... As the engine of the game just cant handle the game itself, its impossible to build mediocre tall cars/buildings, without lagging the other person completely. 
As soon as they fix multiplayer I can recommend this game. But until then, dont get it if you arent in for the singleplayer experience

"Scrap Mechanic" is a fun and engaging building game that allows you to unleash your creativity and build all sorts of contraptions from scrap materials. As a mechanic, you must explore a vast open world full of resources, collect parts and tools, and build everything from simple vehicles to complex machines.

One of the game's strengths is its building system, which is both intuitive and powerful. You can snap parts together in various configurations to create your own unique designs, and the game's physics engine allows you to test and refine your creations in a fun and interactive way.

The game's graphics are also a highlight, with a charming and colorful aesthetic that brings the game world to life. The sound effects and music are catchy and upbeat, adding to the overall enjoyable experience.

The game also offers a variety of different modes, including singleplayer and multiplayer, as well as different challenges and objectives to complete. The multiplayer aspect is particularly engaging, with the ability to collaborate or compete with other players to build the most impressive creations.

One potential downside to the game is that it can be quite challenging, especially when it comes to building complex machines or vehicles. The learning curve can be steep, and the game's complexity may be overwhelming for some players. However, with practice and patience, the game offers a deeply rewarding and satisfying building experience.

Overall, "Scrap Mechanic" is an excellent building game that will appeal to fans of the genre. With its intuitive building system, engaging gameplay mechanics, and immersive multiplayer, it's a great choice for anyone who wants to unleash their creativity and build amazing machines and vehicles from scrap materials. Highly recommended.

I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 16. My son recently started playing Scrap Mechanic and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

An at-fault accident is one in which you or your insurance company will be the one to pay for damages. It will often affect your auto insurance rates if you're found to be the driver at fault for an accident.

You can still be considered the driver at fault even if the police or your insurance company divide the blame 51% to you and 49% to the other party. But some types of accidents are clearer in terms of liability and fault.

Rear-Ending Another Car
You might have been driving too aggressively or following too closely if you hit the back of the car in front of you. Insurance companies will often assume the fault is yours when this happens.1

Driving Under the Influence
It will cast a lot of doubt on any statement you make about your accident if you were driving under the influence (DUI) or driving while intoxicated (DWI). Drunk driving is such a risky practice that it will cause most insurance companies to raise your rates right away. Your license can be suspended in 42 states as well if you receive a DUI or DWI.2

Note
It might even be legal for your insurance company to refuse to make payment for your injuries if you receive a DWI or DUI.

Not Obeying Traffic Signals
It's referred to as a "moving violation" if you don't follow traffic and obey signals, signs, or directives. There are many kinds of moving violations, including driving through a red light, failure to yield, rolling through stop signs, and driving the wrong way down a one-way street.

Your insurance company will assume that you're to blame if you ignore traffic signs or signals and then crash. These types of violations can also result in points being added to your license. More points can result in higher insurance costs.3

Using a Cell Phone While Driving
Using your phone while driving isn't against the law in all states, but texting while driving is banned in 48 states and the District of Columbia as of 2021.4

Being on your phone doesn't always mean that you were at fault if an accident happens, but you should be truthful when telling police what you were doing when you crashed.5

Note
Distracted driving is a big red flag for insurance companies. You can probably count on your insurance rates going up if you're ticketed for texting and driving. Your rates will also increase if you cause a crash or fender bender because you were on your phone.6

How Does At-Fault Accident Insurance Work?
Insurance companies decide who's at fault in an accident by relying on the legal concept of negligence. This means that you failed to act in a way that a reasonable person would act if they were faced with the same situation.

Your insurance company might use "comparative negligence" to assign a percentage of fault to each driver involved in the accident, or it might assign "contributory negligence." The payout you receive could go down based on how much your actions contributed to the incident.7

Each state is unique, but insurance is fault-based in most states. States in which this is the case are also known as "tort" states.

The insurance company of the at-fault driver pays repairs, medical expenses, and other costs in tort states. Medical costs for the insured person are paid by their insurance company, up to a certain amount in no-fault states. Property damage is covered by the at-fault driver's insurance.

What It Means if You're in an At-Fault Accident
The best way to avoid being at fault is to obey the law and drive safely. But you may still be found at fault sometimes. You might make a choice in a split second that ends up being the wrong one.

The best thing to do if you're in a crash or fender bender is to not admit fault at the scene of the crash. Take photos of the damage, and exchange insurance information. Wait for the police to show up. Then give a truthful account of what happened.

The insurance adjuster will review your side of the story, as well as the police report, the other party's version of events, and the damage done. Then they'll decide who was at fault.

Note
The kind of insurance you have will play a big part in what happens next if you're found to be at fault. Bodily injury liability coverage will help pay the medical expenses for you, any other people in your car, and the other driver. Collision coverage pays to repair the car.8

Make sure you understand your state's minimum car insurance requirements. You'll want to have full coverage for personal liability and property damage liability if you're found to be at fault. You can be sued for the additional costs if your insurance doesn't cover the damage to people or property when you cause an accident.

Sometimes you can't avoid an accident. Your insurance rates will often rise when this happens regardless. But there are steps you can take to avoid being the cause of a crash. Put your phone away while driving. Avoid using alcohol or drugs that may impair how well you drive. Obey all the legal and safety rules of the road.

I simply cannot recommend this game.

I played this game with my wife, nearly two years ago now. We played coop survival together, and while it has some fun things to offer, and it's not actually very buggy or anything, it just feels dreadfully short and incomplete. 

And it's just not changing, it's been nearly 2 years. The devs regularly post dev blogs every 2-6 months or so. They've even done an occasional patch. But essentially, there has been no real new content for this game in over 2 years.

For example, enemies in survival mode. There are only 4. The wiki lists 7, and has variant colors of one of the original 4. But, none of that exists yet. All of this has been shown or discussed in dev blogs only. And that's just the tip of the iceberg on this issue. There is a mountain of content that has been shown and discussed in dev blogs.

It's been two years, nothing new has shown up yet.

So the game is good. I love the graphics. I like the overall game play. I think there could be more layers to survival, but I'm biased towards that game play. I'm blown away by all the simple things this game doesn't have.  How is there no Pause? How is there not a map function? Why does it grind systems to a halt while mining resources? These seems like really simple things the devs should have knocked out by now. 

I can't recommend a game just because it's got good bones. There needs to be more progress in fleshing this thing out and it just doesn't look like that's happening. Otherwise I do enjoy bopping in every now and again and doing some building.

Majority of my hours are pre-survival launch. I haven't played this game in literally a year to the day posting this review. This was one of my most cherished games back in my early college days, and I spent so much time waiting for Survival (and being let down by it) that I didn't even notice that no genuine content has been added to the game in nearly two years.

Scrap Mechanic is a fantastic game, and I wish I could've seen this clearly sooner. TLDR: gameplay is too basic, put your drill on some suspension, and you can drill much easier. other than that hurdle, the rest is pretty basic. great mechanics regarding making trucks and machines, just no real reason to do any of it.  

2023 update: they added some stuff, but VERY little. the core aspect of the game is still the same. there is almost no real reason to explore the map, nore a real good reason too. the only reason you would do this is to get the final plants to then harvest those and get the final guns. but there is no reason to do this, because after you get the guns you have absolutely nothing to use them on that you can't already kill easily. the game needs some SERIOUS work. not sure what, but the only thing to explore is the factory. granted, they updated it a bit. more areas inside of it. but it just feels bad to me, running around in circles just trying to find the elevator to the next level. but, it seems like the devs gave up on the game, very few updates. that, or they are ramping up for a huge one. only time will tell. 

i played the game a bit more after the review, not much has changed. it took a long time to really get a handle of how to do things. but i do still think that the drills and saws need to be optimized to just work better i really hated how i had to go over the top just to be able to mine some rocks. this game is not really meant for casual players, but if they optimized some stuff, i could be. 

This game isn't ready yet by far. ive been waiting for survival mode to finally get this game and its REALLY shallow. mining rocks is a serious pain. it takes WAY too long to really get to any point where you can kinda start building stuff. the worst part is you just have your hammer for a LONG time. that's it, just a hammer weapon. the only way to get any other weapons is to go through alot of effort to farm up resources then take them to a place, then get packs to trade for a weapon. im 20 hours in and im at the point to trade, and i just don't care. the game is just too shallow. and i spent like 2 hours just trying to mine these rocks, the drill is such crap. once you FINALLY get it and get to rocks, your drill just bounces off of them, and you don't have any way to control it other than connecting it to your motor, which means you have to drive to run the drill which means pushing your drill off the rocks. i tried making forks with blocks to catch the rocks so the drill sticks a little better, but you still end up hammering all the smaller rocks. there is just too much grind and annoyance to the game. what did it for me is i finally ran out of components to build things and i need to go out and just farm up bots, but if i have to swing my hammer one more time, im gonna kill myself. so im just gonna uninstall instead. they need to add more to make the loop less basic. sure you can make anything, but getting ANY resources is such a pain, its just not worth it. ill be back in a year or so see what new things they have. but for now, not really worth it yet.

I suppose I should edit this review now, as none of what I said earlier even matters anymore.

This game is fun, and addictive in my case, but it's severely plagued by bugs and bad coding. There are some major features to the game that haven't yet been implemented, which is contrary to what the devs said about getting it as perfect as possible when they delayed it.

Currently, what you're looking at is a game that's roughly 75% finished when you discount bugs. So it's fun if you can handle bugs, but be warned some parts are a major grind. I would say right now it's only just a no from me.

UPDATE: This review is nearly 3 years old at this point, it'll probably say older because I've edited it a couple times.

After a short burst of frequent updates following the launch of survival mode, the game at this point gets updated every 12-18 months, rarely any of it bug fixes. The devs are very transfixed on a "chapter 2" for survival, which has been hinted through the highly infrequent dev blogs, so this may appear at some point. Bear in mind the game has been in early access for 7 years as of writing, with the initial trailers for the game having dropped nearly 10 years ago, so this second chapter may be a while.

TL;DR, game is full of bugs that are unlikely to be fixed, gets updated very rarely. It's as close as you can get to abandonware

If you are looking for a game that has both survival and creative freedom, look no further then Scrap Mechanic. This game is a masterpiece that allows you to create and build what you want when you want.  Weather you are looking to make a small cottage, or an expansive base you can do so.  Scrap Mechanic has lots of features that allow you to have an endless imagination when building.

Scrap Mechanic Survival Mode has many difficulties from the environment to the robots that try to attack you when you try and survive.  The survival mode is well rounded off.  As long as you have all the materials   you need to build what your imagination desires survival mode allows you to do so.

If you are looking for a creative game that is laid back Scrap Mechanic Creative Mode is where you can go.  Creative in this game is like some other games where you don't need to worry about food, water, health, or the resources running out.  Where other games fall Creative Scrap Mechanic thrives.  

All in all if you are looking for a game where you can sink loads of hours into, Survival Scrap Mechanic is the game for you.

Scrap Mechanic is a creative and innovative game that offers players a unique experience in building and engineering. The game's graphics are colorful and detailed, creating a charming and immersive environment that encourages creativity and exploration. The game's building mechanics are intuitive and easy to use, allowing players to design and construct their own complex machines and structures. The game's survival mode, which challenges players to gather resources and fend off hostile robots, adds an exciting and engaging aspect to the gameplay. Additionally, the game's multiplayer mode allows players to collaborate and share their creations with others, fostering a strong sense of community and creativity. Overall, Scrap Mechanic is a must-play for anyone who loves building, engineering, and creativity.

I'm not going to say that it was a waste of money the game is fun and looks great. But the problem is that I feel limited to what I can do. First off getting food and water is a struggle I can be full on hunger but then start starving 5-10 minutes later. Second there is a timer that becomes shorter and shorter the more you plant. What happens at the end of the timer is there are robots that attack my farm and take my only source of food and water keep in mind that it take around 25-30 minutes to grow most crops. So my farm is ruined due to there being 5-8 farmer robots that take 5 hits EACH to kill and do an average of 25 damage. So I am 4 hit against 5-8 robots? It makes it hard to progress because I only have 20 minutes to explore and I have to plant food or else I die due to starvation. I understand the game is in beta it just doesn't make sense for that to happen. I don't have friends who own this game and don't really want to play with strangers yet but now I feel scammed and it was a waste of time due to this slow and unbearing progression. Even if I am there on time I always lose some crops due to the sheer amount of robots against 1 person. I really have no hate to the game or the devs I think that this needs to be put out there and it shouldn't be in the game.

*First Impressions Review*

Love this game, as a 1k+ hour player in ARK this might be my new ARK. Gotta say though, not being able to drink water or find an early source of food is a real shame, It created an infinite death loop for me that I had to solve by dying over and over again in order to secure what should have been a basic game mechanic.

Also as a first impression, the fork wielding robots that gang up and chase infinitely from the get-go seems like a challenge better left for a little bit later on, not even ARK pulls that crap and ARK notoriously hates new players.

Awesome game and an easy thumbs up, the depth and possibilities make me think I'll sink hundreds of hours into it, but from a new player experience the gateway is broken IMO.

First few hours of the game can be hard but just watching videos and learning from them is a really good way to learn this game. Also you will never get bored of it because there is so much to build and do. Like in survival there is so much you can do just with no mods adding mods is a whole another story.
hi

Difficulty-
Creative: its easy to understand how to make anything you want within reason, and all of the tools are given to you with decent explanation. You can go from a simple car to a complex flying machine without having to learn every little feature. 
Making simple things, yet the detail is amazing just takes time. After playing creative for a while you realise that some mods almost feel required, the game only gives you 2 types of wheel "big" that is far too big and "small" that is far too small.

Survival: driving far from spawn looking to pick up something cool and then getting one shot by a tape bot and soft locking yourself isn't all that fun. 

Length-
Because of the shear amount of things you can do, you will never feel like there is nothing to build, collect or fight. End game survival can get somewhat boring, though there are 3 other game modes and multiplayer to check out.

Personal Experience-
This being one of the first ever games i had on my steam account, my opinion could be very biased, but all my friends i have played with found it fun. After years of playing i still occasionally play it and never feel like I have ran it out. The cosmetics, though not micro transactions, are still a massive pain to get for people who mostly play creative and make workshop content.

Total score- ⭐⭐⭐⭐/5

Good idea ruined because they went too far without fixing the suspension glitch. Would be awesome if the developers reworked the game like many other "Early Access" games are, it would bring back a lot of the player base and breathe fresh air into the game.

Edit- After a near 6 month break I expected to see some progress from the the Developers in the actual game not teases on Twitter. 

Its a fun game and although the suspension glitch ruins a lot of really cool ideas for vehicles, I believe the games worth $20 but with no recent updates you have to rely on the modders to keep the game feeling "fresh". Still, even after that you gotta take like a week or so long break from it until its fun again.

I follow the rule where if you can have fun playing For a $1 a hour of entertainment the game is worth it. And for $20 id say its definitely a worthy game, but it will get stale quickly with barely any updates...ever...

Overall a very, very good, satisfying, sandbox game. Simple enough for anyone to understand and enjoy, but still has a very high ceiling of capability for those who want to take it there. I see it as an "Upgrade to Minecraft".

Being able to build things in 1st person as a humanoid, is in my opinion, a lot more desirable than building things as a free-cam, and it's the main reason I prefer this sandbox over Trailmakers or Besiege. It keeps things simple. If you know how to play Minecraft, this has the exact same idea, just with more in the mechanical department and less in the architectural.

The physics are pretty good in my opinion. Out of the other few games I've played, I would have to say this one has the best. Things don't feel outrageously heavy is one of the main things I noticed. There are some glitches though which can break the immersion (Suspension Glitch), but there are ways around the glitches.

The mod community is very strong. There are lots of good mod parts that seem like they should have been in the game in the first place. Modders for this game could be seen as equal to the dev team at this point.

Everything also builds on a smaller scale in this game (but not tiny), which is nice because it means you can make more complex and detailed builds, without making them gigantic in relativity to the character.

Survival mode is also really fun for at least a little while. They're still working on it (It's taking wayyy too long), but I think it's pretty neat. The Worldgen and world design are both really good, the story-telling is sufficient, the map is huge, there's secret POIs, and Warehouses are one of the most interesting things in this game to explore. But, there are still a lot of problems.

Progression is not linear at all. You go from very slow progress in the early game, to extremely fast progress in the mid game, which easily takes you to the late game. Warehouses are arguably not rewarding enough upon completion. Some things remain tedious to do or get even in the end-game (Glue and Beeswax). Traction still sucks throughout the entire map when you're using a heavy vehicle.

One of the biggest problems with this game though is the new-content cycle. It's soooo slow. The devs release game-changing content only once every couple of years or more. But when they do finally hit the release, it's a huge amount of stuff. I think a "Smaller Updates/Shorter Wait" would be much more beneficial for this game.

But yeah, it's good overall. Creative mode especially, but Survival is pretty fun too if you ignore some of the problems.

Scrap Mechanic is a fun and engaging sandbox game that offers players the ability to build and create their own machines and contraptions. The graphics are charming and the building mechanics are intuitive and easy to use. The game world is vast and offers plenty of room for players to explore and create. The survival elements, such as managing hunger and thirst, add an extra layer of challenge and depth to the game. The multiplayer aspect of the game allows players to work together and share their creations, making it a social and enjoyable experience. With over 47 hours of gameplay, it's clear that Scrap Mechanic offers a lot of content and replayability. Overall, it's a well-made game that is definitely worth the price for fans of building and crafting games.

[hr][/hr]
Scrap Mechanic is hands down one of the best games I have ever played and I have over 1000 hours on it. It's a game that allows you to build anything you can imagine and is a true test of your creativity. The game has a wide range of tools, materials and parts that you can use to build your contraptions. And with the help of mods, the possibilities are truly endless.

One of the best things about Scrap Mechanic is how accessible it is. Whether you're a seasoned builder or a newcomer, you'll find the game easy to pick up and start building right away. The controls are intuitive and the tutorials are helpful, making it easy to get started.

What makes this game truly special is the community behind it. Players from all over the world have come together to share their creations and mods, making it possible to build truly amazing contraptions. From flying machines to massive, multi-level cities, you'll find all sorts of incredible creations to explore and enjoy.

The only downside to this game is that the lag can sometimes limit your building. When you build something that's very large or complex, you may experience some lag. However, this is a minor issue and doesn't detract from the overall experience.

[hr][/hr]
In conclusion, I give Scrap Mechanic 5 stars. It's a game that truly pushes the limits of what you can build and has a vibrant and supportive community. Whether you're a seasoned builder or just looking for a fun and creative game, Scrap Mechanic is a must-play. ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

This game is the barest of bare bone games I've ever played. It sure look nice, but that's about the only good thing I have to say about this game.

[b]No Blueprints In Survival[/b]

There's the creative mode, and then there's the survival mode. You design something in creative, save the blueprint, then build it in survival and put it to use. Standard practice for those vehicle building games, right?

Except no. That's not how this game works. What you build in creative stays in creative, as there are no blueprint saving or loading feature in survival! The best you can do is to memorize the design in creative then try to manually replicate it in survival.

[b]Repetitive Gameplay[/b]

The survival mode is just one huge grind. You'll need large amounts of scrap metal and component kits to build anything decent, and the ONLY way to obtain scrap metal is by killing the Haybots. Crates drop component kits too but they are often in ruins guarded by Haybots so you'll have to fight them anyway. There are only a few variations of said ruin, so exploration gets old real fast.

So, survival is combat heavy. But how good is the combat system anyway? I'll just say this, there are 4 weapons in this game in total. The hammer you start with is the ONLY melee weapon in this game. The other 3 are guns that shoot potatoes in different ways. (Yeah, potato guns. That's about as awesome as it sounds.) On the other hand, there are 4 types of enemy, but for most of the time you'll only see 2 of them. 

4 types of weapon (actually feels like 2), 4 types of enemy (only 2 are regularly encountered). You can draw your own conclusions.

[b]Ridiculous Numbers[/b]

Apparently the devs went with guesstimation when setting up the numbers. For example, a Thruster costs 10 component kits to build, and another 40 to upgrade to Lv5. And you need at least 4 of them to build a functional hovercraft. How many component kits you get from clearing a ruin? Around 3-6.

Then there's the late game enemy, the Tapebot, encountered in and around the warehouse. It deals 55 damage per shot in normal difficulty. You have 100 HP, and no armor whatsoever. Yes, that means two-hit-kill. Did I mention it's a RANGED enemy with lighting fast reflex and pin-point accuracy? Sufficient to say, if it finds you before you realize it's there, you are dead.

If you think you can handle them by sniping outside the warehouse, wait until you get inside. Where in a cramped environment, they often appear in groups of 2-4, mixed with an even more powerful version. Have fun riding that elevator over and over again to retrieve your corpse!
